document: Doctor: Hello, can you please tell me about your past medical history? Patient: Hi, I don't have any past medical history. Doctor: Okay. What brings you in today? Patient: I've been experiencing painless blurry vision in my right eye for a week now. I've also had intermittent fevers, headache, body aches, and a nonpruritic maculopapular rash on my lower legs for the past 6 months. Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. Have you had any other symptoms such as neck stiffness, nausea, vomiting, Raynaud's phenomenon, oral ulcerations, chest pain, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, or photosensitivity? Patient: No, only an isolated episode of left knee swelling and testicular swelling in the past. Doctor: Do you work with any toxic substances or have any habits like smoking, drinking, or illicit drug use? Patient: No, I work as a flooring installer and I don't have any toxic habits. Doctor: Alright. We checked your vital signs and they were normal. During the physical exam, we found bilateral papilledema and optic nerve erythema in your right eye, which was greater than in your left eye. You also have a right inferior nasal quadrant visual field defect and a right afferent pupillary defect. Your muscle strength and reflexes were normal, and your sensation to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception was intact. We also noticed the maculopapular rash on your bilateral lower extremities. Patient: Oh, I see. Doctor: Your admitting labs showed some abnormal results. You have microcytic anemia with a hemoglobin of 11.6 gm/dL, hematocrit of 35.3%, and mean corpuscular volume of 76.9 fL. You also have hyponatremia with a sodium level of 133 mmol/L. Your erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is elevated at 33 mm/hr, and your C-reactive protein (CRP) is also elevated at 13.3 mg/L. Your urinalysis did not show any protein or blood. Patient: Okay. What does that mean? Doctor: These results could indicate an underlying inflammatory

document: Doctor: Hello, I understand that you're a 7-year-old boy with congenital bilateral sensorineural deafness, and you've had a failed right cochlear implant. Is that correct? Patient: Yes, doctor. Doctor: We recently conducted a Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) before transferring you to the operating theatre for an ABI insertion. During the MRI, your airway was secured with a size 5.5 mm internal-diameter uncuffed ETT. Did you experience any discomfort during the MRI? Patient: No, it was okay. Doctor: Great. Now, during the surgery, we will be performing intraoperative neurophysiology monitoring, which includes brainstem auditory sensory evoked potentials, brainstem mapping of CN IX, X, XI, XII and their motor nuclei, and corticobulbar tract motor-evoked potential (MEP). This will help us monitor your nerves during the procedure. Patient: Okay, doctor. Doctor: Our anesthesia team will be responsible for the lead placement for CN IX, X, XI, XII. We will use a 32 mm by 29 mm laryngeal electrode for CN X monitoring (Fig.). To ensure optimal electrode placement on the tracheal tube, we positioned you as intended for surgery (right lateral) and identified the depth of ETT corresponding to the laryngeal inlet using a C-MAC Laryngoscope. Patient: Hmm, alright. Doctor: This corresponded to 6 cm at vocal cords (15 cm at lips). We then prepared a new #5.5 uncuffed ETT with the laryngeal electrodes (Fig.) and re-intubated you, in keeping with the measurements. Patient: Okay, got it. Doctor: For CN IX placement, we put a pin electrode on the ipsilateral soft palate. For CN XII, we placed electrodes on the anterior tongue. Patient: I see. Doctor: To stabilize the tracheal tube, we used rolled up gauzes on either side of it (Fig.), which also acted as a bite block. Patient: Alright,
prediction: Subjective: The patient is a 7-year-old boy with congenital bilateral sensorineural deafness, and has had an unsuccessful right cochlear implant. He has been undergoing MRI. The airway was secured with size 5.5 mm internal-diameter uncuffed ETT, which corresponded to 6 cm at vocal cords (15 cm) at lips and corticobulbar tract motor-evoked potential (MEP) and re-intubated him for ABI insertion. Introoperative neurophysiology monitoring includes brainstem auditory sensory evoke potentials, brain mapping of CN IX, XII and their motor nuclei. Neurophysiological monitoring is performed on the tracheal tube. Anesthesia team will be responsible for the lead placement of the laryngeal electrodes.
summarization: Subjective: The patient is a 7-year-old boy with congenital bilateral sensorineural deafness, reporting a previously failed right cochlear implant. He denies experiencing discomfort during the recent MRI procedure. Objective: Recent MRI with airway secured using a 5.5 mm internal-diameter uncuffed ETT. Pre-operative preparations for ABI insertion include intraoperative neurophysiology monitoring and placement of various electrodes for nerve monitoring. The anesthesia plan includes Total Intravenous Anesthesia (TIVA) with propofol targeted at a plasma concentration of 3.55.0 mcg/ml and remifentanil dosed at 0.080.3 mcg/kg/min. Assessment: Primary diagnosis is congenital bilateral sensorineural deafness with a failed right cochlear implant. The patient is scheduled for ABI insertion with comprehensive intraoperative monitoring to ensure nerve integrity and anesthesia efficacy. Plan: Proceed with ABI insertion under TIVA. Monitor intraoperative neurophysiology closely. Post-operative care will include close monitoring of recovery and necessary follow

document: Doctor: Hello, we've received your results from the ultrasound we performed in April 2017. It seems that there is a single thyroid nodule present in your left lobe, measuring 1 cm in its largest diameter. We also performed a complete biochemical screening, including tests for TSH, autoantibodies, and calcitonin. Patient: Hmm, what did the screening results show, doctor? Doctor: Your calcitonin level was found to be slightly elevated at 40 ng/mL, which is above the normal range of 1-4.8 ng/mL. To further investigate, we performed a stimulation test with intravenous calcium. Patient: And what did the stimulation test show? Doctor: After the stimulation, your calcitonin levels peaked at 1420 ng/mL, which indicates that surgical treatment is necessary. As a result, you underwent a total thyroidectomy and central neck dissection on the side of the tumor. Patient: Yes, I remember that. How was my recovery after the surgery? Doctor: Your postoperative course was uneventful, with only a slight hypocalcemia recorded in the first day. However, it completely recovered 48 hours after the surgery, and you were discharged. Patient: That's good to hear. What did the tests on the removed tissue show? Doctor: Immunohistochemistry performed on the thyroid nodule revealed the presence of a medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) measuring 1 cm. It is composed of cells with an eosinophilic cytoplasm and has a predominantly expansive growth pattern. A histological examination showed that the tumor cells were positive for calcitonin, Cromogranin A, Synaptofisin, and TTF-1, but negative for the presence of amyloid. Patient: What about the other surrounding tissue? Doctor: Focal foci of C-cells hyperplasia were spread throughout the entire gland. However, none of the lymph nodes in the central compartment showed any signs of metastases. Patient: That's a relief. What other tests were done on the tissue? Doctor: To perform a more detailed analysis, we treated formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded sections with antigen retrieval using citrate buffer at high pH. They were then immunolabeled with a rabbit monoclo

document: Doctor: Hello, can you tell me what brought you here today? Patient: Hi, I've been having a progressive headache, nausea, and vomiting for about a week. I also noticed some right-side weakness, ptosis, and diplopia. Doctor: I see. Let's talk about when you first presented with these symptoms. Did you experience any conscious disturbance? Patient: Yes, I had an acute onset conscious disturbance, and my Glasgow Coma Scale was E3VaM5 at the hospital. Doctor: Okay, we performed a brain computed tomography and found an enhanced brain tumor with necrotic cystic changes. The tumor is located in your left temporal lobe with upward extension to the left basal ganglion and periventricular region, causing perifocal edema and midline shift. Patient: Oh, that sounds serious. Doctor: Yes, it's a serious condition. We performed an emergent craniectomy for tumor removal in December 2006. The pathology revealed pleomorphic, hyperchromatic cells with glassy, astrocytic cytoplasm, as well as hypercellularity, microvascular proliferation, and necrosis, consistent with the diagnosis of classic GBM. Patient: What happened after that? Doctor: You underwent radiotherapy a month later, followed by chemotherapy with temozolomide for six months. Your performance status improved to a Karnofsky Grade of 70, and your clinical condition was stable thereafter. Patient: That's good to hear. Doctor: However, a follow-up brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in June 2014 revealed a new enhanced nodular lesion, about 1.1 cm in diameter, at your left temporal base. The brain MRI in October 2014 showed a progressive change in lesions, with a maximum of 3.0 cm in diameter. Patient: What did you do about that? Doctor: We performed another surgery for gross tumor removal. Histologically, the tumors showed the oligodendroglial component. Neoplastic cells also showed isocitrate dehydrogenase 1 (IDH1) positivity, diffuse p53 positivity, and O6-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) negativity as revealed by immunostaining. Patient:

document: Doctor: Hello, I understand that you have been dealing with hepatocellular carcinoma and had a liver transplantation from a living donor about a year ago. How have you been feeling recently? Patient: Well, lately I developed some severe abdominal pain that has been really bothersome. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. It seems like you have developed severe acute pancreatitis. When you were admitted to the hospital, we started a continuous intravenous infusion of fentanyl at 1200 g/day to control your abdominal pain. Over the course of 10 days, we increased the dose according to your pain intensity, reaching 2400 g/day (MED 240 mg/day). How has your pain been since then? Patient: It's been a little bit better with the fentanyl, but it's still quite painful. Doctor: I see. In addition to the fentanyl, we have also administered a pancreatic enzyme inhibitor, antibiotic, and fluid to help alleviate the pancreatitis and your abdominal pain. We have gradually reduced the continuous fentanyl infusion, and it was discontinued after reaching 240 g/day (10% of the maximum dose). However, you mentioned experiencing nausea/vomiting, elevated blood pressure, and restlessness 12 hours after discontinuation. Is that correct? Patient: Yes, that's right. It was pretty uncomfortable. Doctor: I apologize for the discomfort. To alleviate these symptoms, we resumed the continuous intravenous fentanyl infusion at 240 g/day, and the symptoms disappeared. However, restlessness occurred each time the dose was reduced, so we decided to initiate a transdermal fentanyl patch to taper the opioid more slowly. How has that been working for you? Patient: The patch has been helpful; I've noticed a difference. Doctor: Good to hear. Unfortunately, your pancreatitis with abdominal pain recurred transiently one month later. Therefore, we resumed the continuous intravenous fentanyl infusion and titrated it to 600 g/day. We have been gradually decreasing the dose daily (600, 300, 240, 180, 120, and 60 g/day). As your pancreatitis

document: Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today? Patient: Hi, I've been experiencing some pain in my right chest lately. Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about your background? Are you a smoker? Patient: No, I am a non-smoker. I work as an engineer for a gas company. Doctor: Alright. Have you had any exposure to asbestos in your workplace? Patient: No, I don't think so. Doctor: Let's perform a physical examination to check for any issues in your lungs. [After examination] I noticed a reduction of lung sounds at the right lung basis, but no clinical sign of autoimmune disease. Patient: Hmm, what could be causing the chest pain then? Doctor: We will need to perform a chest X-ray (CXR) to investigate further. [After CXR] The results show a considerable reduction in the right lung volume with associated right pleural effusion. Patient: What does that mean? Doctor: It means there is fluid around your right lung. We should perform more tests to determine the cause. [After tests] All serological, autoimmune, and microbiological tests came back negative. Let's do a computed tomography (CT) scan to get a better view. [After CT] The CT scan revealed a slight reduction in right lung volume with associated right pleural effusion and pleural thickening. Patient: What's the next step? Doctor: We will conduct a supplemental investigation to rule out any history of trauma, tuberculosis, and pneumothorax. We will also perform an echocardiography to exclude pulmonary hypertension, and a diaphragm dysfunction test through phrenic nerve stimulation. [After investigations] All tests were negative. Doctor: We'll proceed with a total body positron emission tomographycomputed tomography (PET-CT) to check for any abnormalities. [After PET-CT] There was a low-intensity hyper-accumulation of 18-FDG in the right pleura with increased concentration in the basal, middle, and posterior pleural surface. The patient also mentioned a significant drop in forced vital capacity over the past three years and recent development of shortness of breath on exertion. Objective: Physical examination revealed reduced lung sounds at the right lung base. Chest X-ray indicated a considerable reduction in right lung volume with associated right pleural effusion. PET-CT showed low-intensity hyper-accumulation of 18-FDG in the right pleura. Surgical lung biopsy identified non-specific fibrinous pleurisy without neoplastic or infectious cells. The patient's condition progressed to restrictive respiratory failure. Assessment: The primary diagnosis is non-specific fibrinous pleurisy with associated pleural effusion and pleural thickening, leading to restrictive respiratory failure. document: Doctor: Hi there, I see you've presented with body weight loss. Can you tell me about any medical history you have? Patient: Yes, I have hypertension and diabetes, but both are well-controlled by medication. Doctor: Okay, thank you for letting me know. We've done some laboratory tests, and the data shows that your hemoglobin is decreased at 9.1 g/dl. However, your tumor markers are within normal limits. Patient: Oh, I see. Doctor: We performed a colonoscopy which revealed a circumferential tumor in your sigmoid colon. A histological examination of the biopsy showed that it's a RAS-mutant adenocarcinoma. The RAF mutational status was not investigated. Patient: Hmm, that doesn't sound good. Doctor: A contrast-enhanced CT scan showed irregular colonic wall thickening with massive involvement of your urinary bladder. There were enlarged regional lymph nodes suggestive of metastases but no distant metastasis. Your pretreatment diagnosis is LACC stage IIIC (T4bN2M0). Patient: So, what's the treatment plan for me? Doctor: We started with a loop transverse colostomy, similar to some other cases. We then planned 6 courses of chemotherapy with CAPOX plus bevacizumab. Patient: How did that go? Doctor: You eventually received 5 courses of CAPOX plus bevacizumab and the remaining 1 course without oxaliplatin due to grade 2 neurotoxicity. A follow-up CT after the neoadjuvant chemotherapy showed significant tumor shrinkage. Patient: That's good news. Doctor: Yes, it is. Thereafter, we performed a sigmoid colectomy and partial resection of your bladder. The postoperative course was uneventful, and you did not suffer from neurogenic voiding dysfunction or urinary incontinence. Patient: I'm relieved to hear that. Doctor: Pathological examination revealed that tumor cells or degeneration was present in less than one third of the entire lesion, which was consistent with grade 1a effect according to the Japanese Classification of Colorectal Carcinoma. Patient: So, what's the final diagnosis? Doctor: The final

document: Doctor: Hello, I heard you have a 6-month history of swelling in the left floor of your mouth, and you were referred to our institution. How can I help you today? Patient: Yes, that's right. I've been experiencing some difficulty in swallowing, but I haven't had any pain or tongue paralysis. Doctor: I see. Let's perform an intraoral examination to better understand the issue. Hmm, I can see a well-defined 3.5  3  2 cm-sized solid, spherical submucosal nodule adjacent to the sublingual gland. It's covered with light bluish smooth mucus. Do you feel any pain when I apply pressure to the tumor? Patient: Yes, I feel slight pain when you press on it. Doctor: Alright. Your tongue's mobility and sensory functions seem to be normal, and I don't detect any lymphadenopathy in the submandibular region on palpation. We'll need to conduct some laboratory tests and an enhanced computed tomography scan to get a clearer picture of the issue. Patient: Okay, I understand. [After the tests] Doctor: Your lab results are all normal, and the enhanced computed tomography scan revealed a 2.8  1.8  2.1 cm-sized well-defined, solid, heterogeneous nodule that doesn't appear to involve the mandible. We also found a nodular lesion occupying the left floor of the mouth with abundant blood flow. No enlarged lymph nodes were detected in the submental or submandibular regions. Patient: So, what does that mean, doctor? Doctor: Based on these findings, our initial clinical impression is that this could be a benign salivary gland tumor, dermoid cyst, or benign connective tissue neoplasm. We will need to schedule you for surgery via an intraoral approach to remove the tumor and further examine it. Patient: Alright, so what will the surgery involve? Doctor: During the surgery, we'll make an elliptical incision around the periphery of the sublingual gland, and prepare a full-thickness tissue flap along the lingual aspect of the sublingual gland. Patient: I've been experiencing tingling and numbness in my right arm and leg for at least a month. Doctor: Do you smoke, drink alcohol, or use any drugs? Patient: No, I don't smoke, drink alcohol, or use drugs. Doctor: Your daughter mentioned that you've had an unsteady gait and needed assistance when moving. Is that correct? Patient: Yes, that's true. It's been really hard for me to walk lately. Doctor: Okay, let's review your vital signs from the day of admission. Your temperature was 97.9 F, heart rate 68 beats/min, blood pressure 137/84 mmHg, and respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute. You were alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Now, let's discuss your neurological examination findings. You showed right-sided hemiparesis and significant leg stiffness. Your strength in your right arm was 4/5, and in your right leg, it was 3/5. Your left side was unremarkable. Patient: Yeah, I've been having difficulty moving my right side. Doctor: We also found that your cranial nerves 2-10 were normal, but you had difficulty shrugging your right shoulder and couldn't turn your head to the left. When walking, your gait was unsteady, and you compensated with your non-affected side. The rest of your physical examination was within normal limits. Patient: Okay, what about the tests you did on me? Doctor: Your laboratory values were within normal limits. We performed a head computed tomography (CT) and a follow-up magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), which were both negative for a stroke. However, your cervical spine CT showed marked degenerative changes, including moderate to severe spinal canal stenosis at C4/C5. Patient: Oh, what does that mean? Doctor: We performed an MRI of your cervical spine without contrast, which confirmed the moderate to severe central stenosis with cord compression and mildly increased T2 signal at C4/C5 and C5/C6.

Patient: Yeah, I've been having this pain in my right upper abdomen, and it's been quite bothersome. Doctor: Hmm, it sounds like you may have a positive Murphy's sign. You were referred to our department for further evaluation and possible surgical treatment. We performed a Computed Tomography (CT) scan without contrast media, which revealed a gallstone in your thickened gallbladder wall. There was also a slight increase in the CT value due to surrounding panniculitis, as shown in Fig. Patient: Oh, I see. So what does that mean for me? Doctor: We also conducted an MRCP, which showed that your cystic duct is connected to an aberrant bile duct. Based on these findings, you were diagnosed with chronic calculous cholecystitis with aberrant bile duct flow into the cystic duct. Patient: Okay, so what's the next step for treatment? Doctor: We performed a laparoscopic cholecystectomy to address the issue. During the procedure, we placed four ports: a 12-mm camera port in the umbilical area, a 12-mm port in the epigastric area, a 5-mm port in the right subcostal area, and a 5-mm port at the right lateral abdomen. Patient: How did the surgery go? Doctor: Due to the inflammatory fibrotic adhesion in Calot's triangle, the aberrant right hepatic duct (ARHD) was excessively exposed. We used a fundus-first technique to confirm the ARHD after exposing the inner layer of the subserosal layer at the dorsal and ventral side of Calot's triangle. We confirmed that the ARHD drained into the cystic duct. Patient: Was there any need to preserve the ARHD? Doctor: Preoperative MRCP suggested that it was not necessary to preserve the ARHD, as it seemed to be closed at the hepatic side without communicating with the major right branch of the intrahepatic bile duct. document: Doctor: Hi there! I see you've presented with hoarseness and dysphagia for the past three months following an upper respiratory infection. Can you tell me more about your symptoms? Patient: Yeah, my voice has been really hoarse, and I've had trouble swallowing too. Doctor: I understand. I also noticed in your past medical history that you had invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast, which was ER positive, PR negative, and HER2 negative. You were treated with a mastectomy two years prior to this presentation. Is that correct? Patient: Yes, that's right. Doctor: During the clinical examination, we found paralysis of your right vocal cord. We also performed a CT scan of your neck, which revealed an enlarged thyroid gland with multiple bilateral thyroid nodules. Have you experienced any other symptoms? Patient: No, not really. Just the hoarseness and difficulty swallowing. Doctor: Okay. We performed a fine needle aspiration (FNA) of a right-sided 3.5 cm thyroid nodule, which was initially diagnosed as atypia of undetermined significance, falling under Bethesda category III. We did a repeat FNA three months later, and it yielded a diagnosis of benign follicular nodule, which is Bethesda category II. Patient: I see. Doctor: Due to your persistent hoarseness and compressive symptoms, as well as the atypical findings on the initial FNA, we decided to proceed with a right thyroid lobectomy and a right vocal cord injection. Intraoperatively, we observed that your right thyroid lobe was moderately enlarged with multiple nodules but no evidence of extrathyroidal extension. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: The right lobectomy specimen measured 4.6 cm in greatest dimension and weighed 16 grams. Upon further examination, we found multiple variably sized brown gelatinous nodules with focal areas of hemorrhage and cystic change in the thyroid parenchyma. Patient: What does that mean? Doctor: The histologic examination revealed evidence of nodular thyroid hyperplasia. document: Doctor: Hello, I wanted to discuss your current situation and review your surgical history with you. Can you tell me what brought you to our facility initially? Patient: Yes, I came in with a strangulated large bowel and ventral hernia, 10 years after my LAGB procedure. Doctor: That's correct. At that time, you were still morbidly obese and had been lost to follow-up. We performed an emergency surgical hernia repair, which included resection of the necrotic transverse colon, and created a loop ileostomy. One year later, you presented with a LAGB port-site infection. Do you remember what we did during that time? Patient: Yes, you removed the port and sutured the tubing to my abdominal wall. Doctor: Exactly. During both admissions, we observed the LAGB tubing in a stable position adjacent to the transverse colon on the CT scans, with no concerns for penetration. Six months after the port-site infection, we elected to reverse the ileostomy. However, there were complications in the early post-operative period. Can you tell me about those symptoms? Patient: I remember feeling really sick and ended up having abdominal sepsis. Doctor: Yes, that's correct. The abdominal CT demonstrated transection of the remaining proximal transverse colon by the LAGB tubing. Due to this, we had to perform a right hemicolectomy, which involved the removal of the gastric band and tubing, and we created an end ileostomy. Patient: Oh, I see. So, what's the plan moving forward, doctor? Doctor: Our main focus now is to ensure proper healing and monitor for any complications. We'll keep a close eye on your progress and address any issues that may arise. Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate all the care you've provided, and I'll make sure to follow your instructions and communicate any concerns. Doctor: You're welcome. Remember that your health and well-being are our top priorities. Don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or need assistance. We're here to help.

document: Doctor: Congratulations on your newborn baby girl! She was delivered via vaginal delivery at 40 weeks and 5 days gestational age, right? Mother: Yes, that's correct. Doctor: I understand that you, the 29-year-old mother, had an uncomplicated pregnancy. Is that correct? Mother: Yes, everything went smoothly. Doctor: Good to hear. The physical exam at birth was unremarkable, and all her growth parameters were proportionate and appropriate for her gestational age. Mother: That's a relief. Thank you. Doctor: We enrolled your baby in the well-baby cohort of the BabySeq Project. She was randomized to undergo whole-exome sequencing with analysis limited to genes strongly associated with pediatric-onset disorders. Mother: Oh, okay. What does that mean? Doctor: It means we conducted a genetic test to check for any potential health issues that could arise during her childhood. The good news is that there were no major health concerns, surgeries, or hospitalizations between her well-baby nursery discharge and the time genomic results were reported at 2.5 months of age. Mother: That's great to hear. Doctor: Now, regarding your baby's family history, both maternal and paternal families are of European ancestry, with no known consanguinity, correct? Mother: Yes, that's right. Doctor: I noticed that there is a history of severe eczema in your 17-month-old son and two distant paternal relatives reported to have alopecia, one with an onset as a teenager. Is that correct? Mother: Yes, that's true. Doctor: While these conditions may have a genetic component, your baby's genetic analysis did not indicate any immediate concerns. However, it's important to monitor her health and report any unusual symptoms or concerns to her pediatrician. Mother: Yes, we'll definitely keep an eye on her. Doctor: Great. Remember to schedule regular check-ups and follow the recommended vaccination schedule to ensure her continued health and well-being. Mother: We will. Thank you, Doctor. Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns in the future, don't hesitate to reach out. Congratulations again on your beautiful baby girl!

The 29-year-old mother reported an uncomplicated pregnancy and no major health concerns, surgeries, or hospitalizations for the baby post-discharge. The family history includes severe eczema in a sibling and alopecia in distant paternal relatives. Objective: Physical examination at birth was unremarkable with growth parameters appropriate for gestational age. The baby underwent whole-exome sequencing as part of the BabySeq Project, revealing no significant genetic concerns related to pediatric-onset disorders. Assessment: The newborn is currently healthy with no immediate genetic health concerns identified. Family history suggests a predisposition to conditions like eczema and alopecia, which may warrant monitoring. Plan: Plan to monitor the baby's health through regular pediatric check-ups and adherence to the recommended vaccination schedule. Educate the mother on signs of common genetic conditions like eczema and alopecia given the family history. Encourage the mother to report any unusual symptoms or concerns to the pediatrician.

document: Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today? Patient: Hi, doctor. I'm a 48-year-old woman and I've noticed a palpable mass in the distal phalanx of my left ring finger. I have a history of enchondroma in the same location. Doctor: I see. Let's perform an ultrasound examination to get a better understanding of the mass. (Doctor conducts the ultrasound examination) Doctor: The ultrasound examination revealed an exophytic hypoechoic mass that is connected to the medullary cavity through the interrupted bone cortex. There are no obvious blood signals or calcification in this area. Unfortunately, it's difficult to characterize or classify the mass using traditional ultrasound methods. Patient: Oh, I see. So, what does that mean for me, doctor? Doctor: Based on the ultrasound findings, we can confirm that there is a mass located close to the bone. However, due to the limitations of the ultrasound, we cannot precisely determine the nature of the mass. We have included these findings in our ultrasound diagnostic report. Patient: Hmm, so what's the next step? Doctor: The next step would be a more detailed examination, such as an MRI or a biopsy, to better understand the nature of the mass and determine the appropriate treatment options. Patient: Okay, when can we schedule that? Doctor: I'll have my assistant schedule the MRI or biopsy for you as soon as possible. In the meantime, please monitor any changes in the mass or if you experience any discomfort or pain. Patient: Alright, thank you, doctor. Doctor: You're welcome. We'll be in touch with you to schedule the further examination. Please don't hesitate to contact us if you have any concerns or questions in the meantime.

document: Doctor: Hello PT, how can I help you today? PT: Hey doc, I've been having some issues with memory lately. I've been experiencing recurrent amnesia when I wake up, with disorientation and repetitive questioning, which only lasts for a few minutes. Doctor: I see, any other symptoms you've been experiencing? PT: Yeah, I've also had these 30-second trance-like episodes during the day. My partner reported that sometimes I make repetitive swallowing movements, followed by disorientation and repetitive questioning. These episodes occur in clusters of up to seven per day. Doctor: Are you aware of these episodes when they happen? PT: Well, I'm aware of some of them, but not all. I do have partial recollection of being unable to remember things during those times. Doctor: Have you noticed any other changes in your memory? PT: Yes, I've noticed that I lose newly acquired memories over days, and I have difficulty recalling autobiographical events from my adulthood and familiar routes. Doctor: Have you experienced any other symptoms along with these memory issues? PT: I've developed olfactory hallucinations that smell like candy floss, which can last for up to a day and seem to happen independently of the amnestic episodes. I also feel like my sense of smell has become a bit blunted. Plus, I've been having headaches with migrainous features, postural arm tremor, tingling in my legs, malaise, and low mood. Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. Can you tell me about your medical history? PT: My medical history is mostly unremarkable, but I did have symptoms of depression last year and a history of heavy alcohol use in the past. Doctor: Based on your symptoms, we conducted several tests and investigations. Your initial brain MRI showed subtly increased T2 signal in the right hippocampus, even in the absence of any recent episodes. Your EEG was normal, and the clinical examination revealed no focal neurological signs. We made an initial clinical diagnosis of TEA. Doctor: We started treating you with lamotrigine, starting at 25 mg and gradually increasing it up to 100 mg twice a day. This resolved your trance-like and amnestic

document: Doctor: Hello, I understand you have a past medical history that includes a two-year history of umbilical hernia, diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, gout, chronic kidney disease with proteinuria, diverticulosis, obesity, and osteoarthritis. What brings you to the clinic today? Patient: Hi, doctor. Over the past two months, I've developed pain in my umbilical hernia. The pain is localized to the periumbilical region and left lower back. It gets worse with food intake, and sometimes I take a 5 mg hydrocodone tablet to relieve it. Doctor: I see. Have you experienced any other symptoms in this period? Patient: Yes, I have had nausea and lost fifteen pounds because I've been eating less. Doctor: Thank you for the information. During your physical examination, we found a 1 cm tender and irreducible mass superior to the umbilicus. We performed a herniorrhaphy, and the gross examination of the surgical specimen did not reveal any masses or lesions. However, the microscopic evaluation showed diffuse infiltration of the connective tissue by malignant cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Patient: Oh no, that sounds serious. What does that mean? Doctor: There were also focal areas of gland formation with mucin production, which is consistent with adenocarcinoma. Immunohistochemistry showed that the neoplastic cells were strongly positive for pancytokeratin and CK7, and negative for CK20, CDX2, TTF-1, and PSA. Patient: What do the laboratory findings show? Doctor: Your lab results showed elevated levels of CA 19-9 (16,590 U/mL) and CEA (14.2 ng/mL). We performed a subsequent computed tomography scan with intravenous contrast, which revealed a 5.0  2.7 cm ill-defined and hypoattenuating mass located in the pancreatic tail and body, with peripancreatic fat infiltration and vascular involvement of the splenic artery and vein. Patient: Are there any other findings from the imaging? Doctor: Yes, the imaging also showed peritoneal carcinomatosis

document: Doctor: Hello, can you please tell me about your obstetric history? Patient: I've been pregnant 6 times, had 3 normal deliveries and 2 induced abortions. Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. What brings you to our emergency department today? Patient: I've been having an acute and persistent dull pain in the right lower quadrant of my abdomen for the past few hours, and I'm really worried about it. Doctor: I see. Are there any other symptoms you're experiencing, such as sweating, nausea, or vomiting? Patient: Yes, I've been having rebound pain, cold sweating, and nausea, but no vomiting. There aren't any factors that seem to relieve or aggravate the pain. Doctor: Okay. When was your last menstrual cycle? Patient: It was about 7 weeks and 4 days ago. Doctor: Do you have a history of pelvic inflammatory disease? Patient: No, I don't. Doctor: Can you tell me about your past medical history? Have you had any infections or procedures? Patient: I had a human papilloma virus infection, and I received 3 doses of the Gardasil vaccination about 7 years ago. I also had an intrauterine device inserted 4 years ago, was diagnosed with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia 3, had a cervical conization procedure 3.5 years ago, and underwent laparoscopic tubal sterilization about 1 year and 4 months ago. Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. During your initial physical examination, we noticed abdominal stiffness and tenderness upon palpation. We also conducted a urine pregnancy test, and it came back positive. A transvaginal ultrasound showed no evidence of intrauterine pregnancy, but we did find a right adnexal mass and minimal ascites. Your lab data revealed a serum -hCG level of 15795 million IU/mL, a white blood cell count of 12300/L, and a hemoglobin level of 11.9 g/dL. Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good. What does that mean? Doctor: Based on your symptoms, clinical signs, imaging, and high level of serum -hCG, we highly suspect an ectopic pregnancy. We will admit you for a surgical intervention tomorrow

document: Doctor: Hi there, how can I help you today? Patient: Hi, I'm 12 years old and I've had a fever, abdominal pain, and painful urination since yesterday. Doctor: I see. Have you had any recent illnesses or tested positive for anything? Patient: Yeah, I tested positive for COVID-19 eight days ago. Doctor: Alright, thank you for letting me know. I will need to perform an abdominal examination to better understand your symptoms. Is that okay with you? Patient: Yes, that's fine. [Doctor performs the examination] Doctor: Your examination findings show that you have superficial and deep tenderness in your right lower abdominal quadrant when I palpate, and localized tenderness when I use percussion. I'm going to order an abdominal ultrasound to get a clearer picture of what's going on. [Ultrasound results come in] Doctor: Your ultrasound results show findings consistent with acute complicated appendicitis. Because of this, we will start you on intravenous antimicrobial treatment, which includes cefotaxime and metronidazole. We'll also need to take you to the operating room for a laparoscopic appendectomy. Patient: Oh, okay. What does the surgery involve? Doctor: A laparoscopic appendectomy is a minimally invasive surgery to remove your inflamed appendix. We'll make a few small incisions in your abdomen, insert a laparoscope to view the area, and then remove the appendix. Patient: Will you test the fluid in my abdomen too? Doctor: Yes, we will take a fluid culture during the surgery to identify any bacteria that may be present. [After the surgery] Doctor: The surgery went well, and we were able to remove your inflamed appendix. The fluid culture revealed the presence of P. aeruginosa, Str. viridans, and Gemella morbillorum bacteria. We will continue your antibiotic treatment to ensure a full recovery. Patient: Thank you, Doctor. Doctor: You're welcome. We will monitor your progress closely, and if you have any concerns or questions, please don't hesitate to ask.

Fluid culture revealed P.aeruginosa, Str. viridans and Gemella morbillorum bacteria. During the surgery, the patient will continue antibiotic treatment to ensure full recovery

document: Doctor: Hello, I see you've been admitted to the emergency department with dyspnea and swelling on your hands and face for at least three days. Can you tell me more about your symptoms? Patient: Yes, I've been having trouble breathing and the swelling has been getting worse. I'm a nonsmoker and don't have any chronic diseases. Doctor: I understand. Due to the worsening dyspnea and hypoxemia, you were initially treated with noninvasive mechanical ventilation. However, since your condition worsened, you were intubated and invasive mechanical ventilation was used. On your physical examination, we auscultated mild crackles bilateral on the lower lung zones. Your chest X-ray showed bilateral nonhomogenous infiltration at the middle and lower zones. Patient: Oh, that sounds serious. document: Doctor: Hello, I see that you're a 50-year-old Chinese man with no prior illnesses. Can you tell me what brought you here today? Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been having a fever, headache, and vomiting for about a month now. Doctor: I see. We performed a Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) of your brain and it showed multiple varying sizes of ring-enhancing lesions scattered in both cerebral and cerebellar hemispheres. This suggests either a metastatic brain tumour or an infection. We also did a Computer Tomographic (CT) scan of your thorax and found a 6.5 cm x 4.5 cm mass in the right upper lobe, which is suspicious for primary lung malignancy. Patient: Oh no, that sounds serious. Doctor: Yes, we needed to investigate further. Your blood tests showed mild leucocytosis of 11.7 x 103/uL and a normal C-reactive protein of 1.5 mg/L. We also performed a lumbar puncture to check your cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). It demonstrated raised intracranial pressure of 26 cm H2O, elevated cell count of 260 cells/mm3 with 90% lymphocyte predominance, low glucose of 1.9 mmol/L, and raised protein at 1.15 g/L. Patient: What do those numbers mean, Doctor? Doctor: These results indicate an infection. Initial mucicarmine and India Ink staining did not demonstrate organisms, but further tests detected CSF cryptococcal antigen, and CSF fungal culture grew C. gattii. Doctor: That's correct. We performed a bronchoscopy to further evaluate the right upper lobe mass. The bronchoalveolar lavage showed thick-walled fungal yeast forms with narrow-based budding, consistent with Cryptococcus yeasts. These were highlighted by mucicarmine special stain. The bronchoscopic biopsies showed non-specific chronic inflammatory infiltrates

document: Doctor: Hello, I see you're a 36-year-old woman with a weight of 50 kg and a height of 147 cm. You've been diagnosed with CIPA and are scheduled for revision of your left total hip arthroplasty. Can you tell me about your symptoms? Patient: Yeah, ever since I was born, I've had recurrent episodes of unexplained fever, anhidrosis, burns, and bone fractures. Doctor: I see. You've also previously undergone 7 operations for spinal deformity and 1 operation of total hip arthroplasty on both sides, correct? Patient: Yes, that's right. Doctor: Although you lack general diaphoresis and thermal nociception, you mentioned that you perform body surface cooling at your own discretion when you feel at risk of hyperthermia, and your body temperature is kept approximately at 36°C? Patient: Yeah, I do that to prevent overheating. Doctor: Good to know. We didn't observe any signs of mental retardation or orthostatic hypotension. Also, no abnormalities were detected on your chest radiographs and electrocardiograms. Your blood biochemistry showed no abnormality except mild anemia, indicated by a hemoglobin level of 10.6 g/dl. Patient: Okay, got it. Doctor: No premedication was administered before your surgery. After you were brought into the operating room, we started routine monitoring and measurement of the bispectral index (BIS). Your body temperature was measured at the urinary bladder, esophagus, and precordial skin and controlled by a hot-air-type heater. Patient: Hmm, okay. Doctor: We administered Propofol at an effect-site concentration of 4 g/ml by target-controlled infusion. After muscle relaxation was achieved by the administration of 50 mg of rocuronium, your trachea was intubated. Patient: Yes, I remember that. Doctor: Immediately after endotracheal intubation, your systolic blood pressure increased from 130 to 145 mmHg, and your heart rate increased from 60 to 95 beats per minute (bpm). Two minutes later, your systolic blood pressure had decreased to 125 mmHg.

document: Doctor: Hello, what brings you in today? Patient: Hi doctor, I was playing golf with some friends and one of them, who is inexperienced, accidentally hit me with a golf ball. I was watching the shot about 5 meters away, 15 degrees left of the player. It hit my lower leg and now I have severe pain. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Let me ask you a few questions. Do you have any medical, family, or psychosocial history that could be relevant? Patient: No, there's no such history. Doctor: Alright. Let's proceed with an X-ray examination to assess the damage to your leg. (After the X-ray) Doctor: The X-ray results show that you have a displaced fracture of the distal one-third of the tibia (Fig., ). We're going to treat this with an intramedullary nail (Fig., ). Patient: Oh, okay. What does that entail? Doctor: It's a surgical procedure in which a metal rod is inserted into your broken bone to stabilize and align it while it heals. Patient: I see. What is the recovery process like? Doctor: You'll have a postoperative follow-up at 6 weeks, then at 3 months, 6 months, 9 months, and finally at 12 months. We'll monitor your progress and ensure that your leg is healing properly. Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate the explanation. Doctor: You're welcome. Please be cautious in the future and take care of your leg during the healing process. If you have any concerns or questions, don't hesitate to reach out. Patient: I will. Thanks again for your help.

document: Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today? Patient: Hi, I've been having trouble swallowing for about 4 months now. Doctor: I see. Has this been accompanied by any pain? Patient: No, there's been no pain. Doctor: Have you experienced any haemoptysis, or coughing up blood? Patient: No, I haven't. Doctor: Are there any other symptoms or signs you'd like to report? Doctor: Upon examination, I found a bulky mass localized to your left tonsillar bed. However, there is no presence of mucosal ulceration. Patient: Oh, what does that mean? Doctor: It means that there is a growth in your tonsil area, but there is no ulceration in the mucous membrane. Additionally, there is no clinical evidence of any pathological cervical lymph nodes. Patient: So, what's the next step? Doctor: I would like to schedule a maxillofacial CT scan and an MRI for further evaluation. Patient: Okay, when should I schedule those? Doctor: As soon as possible, so we can determine the cause of your dysphagia and devise an appropriate treatment plan. Patient: Alright, thank you for your help. Doctor: You're welcome. We'll discuss the results of the CT scan and MRI once they're complete, and determine the best course of action.

document: Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today? Patient: Hi, I got this high voltage electrical burn on my scalp and I was treated with dressing for 10 days in another hospital. But now, I have a fever and an infected wound. Doctor: I see. Do you have any history of immune compromise? Patient: No, I don't. Doctor: Alright. We'll have to do a debridement of your scalp to remove the infected tissue. Unfortunately, even after the debridement, you may still have a sustained fever and raised counts. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Two days after the debridement, we'll do a clinical examination. We might find hyphae over the wound margin and gangrenous changes over your scalp surrounding the wound. Patient: That sounds serious. Doctor: Yes, this could be an invasive fungal infection called zygomycosis. We'll start you on an injection of amphotericin B and take you for a wide debridement. We'll also take a tissue biopsy for histopathology examination. Patient: Alright. Doctor: During the procedure, we'll perform outer bony cortex chiseling with a high-speed diamond burr. The histopathology report will help us identify the specific fungus causing the infection, which in your case is A. corymbifera. Intravenous amphotericin B injection will be continued for a 4-week period since diagnosis to complete healing. Patient: Okay, I understand. Doctor: After two weeks of anti-fungal treatment, your clinical condition should improve. Once we confirm the absence of the fungal infection, we'll cover the scalp defect with a free anterior lateral thigh flap. Patient: Oh, that's good news. Doctor: Yes, the recipient vessels will be the superior temporal artery and vein. In the post-operative period, you'll continue to receive intravenous amphotericin B injection for 2 more weeks. Patient: I see. Doctor: The post-operative period should be uneventful, and your condition will improve over time. Just make sure to follow our instructions carefully and keep an eye on your symptoms. Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help.

We conducted a brain MRI which demonstrated the presence of a large lobulated multicompartmental supra-sellar mass, centered within the hypothalamus/optic chiasm, measuring 5.4cm x 3.4cm x 5cm. This mass has some effect on the midbrain and third ventricle, causing obstructive hydrocephalus. Patient: Oh no, that sounds serious. Doctor: Yes, it is a serious condition. We performed an endoscopic biopsy and septostomy, along with a right-sided ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt to manage your hydrocephalus. Patient: What does that mean for my treatment? Doctor: We started you on chemotherapy with vincristine and carboplatin. Unfortunately, your tumor showed rapid progression with worsening hydrocephalus six weeks into chemotherapy. Patient: Oh, that's not good. Doctor: No, it's not. Due to the progression, you developed further complications like progressive right-sided hemiparesis, bitemporal hemianopia, central hypothyroidism, and feeding difficulties requiring a gastrostomy tube and placement of a second VP shunt. document: Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today? Patient: Hi, I presented to the emergency department because I've been experiencing extreme breathlessness and profuse diaphoresis within the last 2 hours. Doctor: I see. Let's start with a physical examination. *After the examination* Your blood pressure is increased, and your oxygen saturation is low. I also noticed some bilateral basal pulmonary end-inspiratory rales upon auscultation of your chest. Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good. Doctor: We'll need to perform an electrocardiography (ECG) to check for any myocardial injury pattern. *After the ECG* The ECG results do not demonstrate an acute myocardial injury pattern, which is a good sign. Patient: That's a relief. Doctor: We also took a chest radiography, which showed bilateral diffuse infiltrations, Kerley B lines, and flow inversion. Furthermore, we tested your cardiac serum markers (high-sensitivity troponin I using Architect STAT assay by Abbott Diagnostics) and performed a D-dimer test, both of which came back negative. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We also conducted an echocardiographic assessment which disclosed mild concentric hypertrophy, mildly impaired left ventricular systolic function without regional wall motion abnormalities, and moderate diastolic dysfunction with elevated filling pressure. Based on all this information, we have diagnosed you with acute pulmonary edema. Patient: Oh no, what does that mean? Doctor: It means fluid has built up in your lungs, making it difficult for you to breathe. We will need to hospitalize you under closed monitoring in the intensive care unit to treat this condition. Patient: Alright. Doctor: We will administer furosemide and glyceryl trinitrate intravenously and an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor orally, in combination with oxygen support. This should help subside your acute heart failure symptoms. Patient: How long will it take for me to recover? Doctor: Complete respiratory recovery should occur in approximately 12 hours. During the second day of hospitalization, we will perform another ECG to check for any T-wave inversion. If needed, you will also undergo coronary angiography to rule out significant coronary

document: Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today? Patient: Hi, I've been experiencing some issues with my left eye. I noticed a thickening of the iris, and it's been bothering me. Doctor: I see. Let's perform a gonioscopy to take a closer look at the root of the iris in your left eye. (After performing the gonioscopy) Doctor: The gonioscopy revealed a pigmented fusiform thickening of the iris root in your left eye. We also did an ultrasound biomicroscopy (UBM) which showed the presence of a well-circumscribed dome-shaped mass at the level of the ciliary body, between the 2:30 and 3 o'clock positions. The lesion is 8.18 mm large, 7.74 mm long, and 4.88 mm thick. It appears to be a melanoma of the ciliary body, involving the adjacent iris root. Patient: Oh no, that sounds serious. What's the next step? Doctor: In July 2008, you underwent brachytherapy using 106Ru. You received 100 Gy at the apex, with a dose rate of 79.09 cGy/hr, and a total rate at the sclera of 531.1 Gy, with a dose rate of 420.1 cGy/hr. Patient: Okay, I remember that treatment. Did it help? Doctor: One year later, you showed some scleral thinning and a prolapse of uveal tissue at the limbus, corresponding to the site of the preexisting lesion. UBM showed a local scleral extension of the tumor under the conjunctival layer, 0.88 mm thick. Your best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) was 20/20. Patient: So, what was the next step? Doctor: The patient underwent a radical block excision of the sclera, ciliary melanoma, and adjacent iris tissue. This was done by performing a peripheral iridectomy through the opening of the sclera, combined with a corneal tectonic graft,

Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Can you tell me about your medical history? Patient: I had a pelvic exenteration and a permanent end colostomy for stage IIIb cervical cancer. About two years later, I developed a parastomal hernia. Doctor: I see. On this admission, you were diagnosed with an incarcerated parastomal hernia. We performed an emergency laparotomy, resecting more than one-and-a-half meters of gangrenous bowel and re-fashioning the stoma. A surgical mesh was applied with primary closure. The surgery was successful, and you were transferred to the ICU for monitoring. Patient: Hmm, okay. Doctor: About a week later, you became pyrexial and didn't respond well to treatment. CT imaging showed a five-centimeter collection over the mesh. We then opened and explored the wound in the ICU and completed debridement. Patient: Oh, I see. Doctor: The wound dimensions were initially 20 cm x 23 cm x 5 cm, exposing the rectus sheath. To ensure healing, we used the VeraFloTM Vacuum with instillation dressing at -125 mmHg. We cycled a sterile saline solution for three hours before applying the vacuum. Patient: Yes, I remember that. Doctor: We changed the dressing three times a week. Before each replacement, we soaked the dressing in saline solution for 20 minutes. After seven weeks, the wound reduced to 9 cm x 5 cm x 1.6 cm. Patient: That's great to hear. It's nontender and palpable bimanually. The rest of your oropharynx and laryngopharynx appear normal, and there are no palpable neck nodes. Your vitals and blood parameters are also stable. We also did a CT scan of your head and neck, which revealed a well-defined cystic lesion measuring 2.6x21x19 mm3 in the right buccal space, arising from the buccinator muscle and displacing the zygomaticus major. Patient: So what does all that mean? Doctor: Based on these findings, we've made a provisional diagnosis of a right buccal cyst. We planned for an excision biopsy under general anesthesia and performed surgery with our team of ORL Head and Neck Surgeons. Patient: How did the surgery go? Doctor: Intraoperatively, we found a well-defined cystic lesion measuring around 3x3 cm2 in the right buccal space. The cyst contained thick mucinous fluid. We sent the specimen for histopathological examination, and the findings were consistent with an oncocytoma. Patient: Oh, I see. Doctor: After the surgery, we kept you on intravenous antibiotics. document: Doctor: Hello, I understand that you were referred to us for management of fetal demise. Can you tell me about your antenatal visits and any symptoms you've experienced during your pregnancy? Patient: Yes, I attended 3 antenatal visits at a health center. They documented my fundal height at each visit and gave me routine care. I had occasional painful fetal kicks, but I was otherwise well throughout the antenatal period. Doctor: It's good that you had regular visits. When did you start to notice reduced fetal movements? Patient: Hmm, about three days before I got admitted to your service, I noticed the reduced movements, so I consulted at the health center, and they said it was fetal demise. Doctor: I see. When you were admitted to our unit, we checked your vital parameters and found them to be stable. There was no abdominal tenderness, and your fundal height was 32cm. Fetal parts were not easily palpable, and we couldn't perceive fetal heart tones. Also, there were no signs of per vaginal bleeding. Your cervix was long, posterior, firm, and closed. We requested an emergency ultrasound scan, which confirmed the fetal demise and showed gross cranial deformation. However, it didn't diagnose an intra-abdominal location. Patient: That's really sad. So, what did you do next? Doctor: We started cervical ripening with 50g of misoprostol vaginally every 6 hours. After 4 applications, your cervix remained unchanged. So, we decided to proceed with operative delivery to avoid failed induction and reduce the risk of disseminated intravascular coagulation. Patient: What did you find during the operation? Doctor: The intraoperative findings showed a third-degree macerated female fetus floating freely in the peritoneal cavity, weighing 2650g with a tight cord round her neck, and there was no amniotic sac. The uterus was about 14 weeks, and the fallopian tubes and ovaries were normal. The placenta was implanted on the ascending colon and mesocolon. We decided to leave the placenta in place as there were no intraoperative complications encountered.

document: Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today? Patient: Hi, I'm here because I fell from a bunk bed nine days ago and I hurt my left wrist. I got it checked at another facility and they put a splint on it, but I wanted a second opinion. Doctor: I see. Do you have a history of any other medical issues or injuries? Patient: Hmm, well, I've had some issues with intravenous drug abuse and I've been incarcerated before. Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. Let's take a look at your wrist. I'll need to remove the splint and take new X-rays to assess the situation. Patient: Sure, go ahead. document: Doctor: Hello, I see you're here for an evaluation of your new-onset headaches that developed after coitus several weeks ago. Can you describe these headaches to me? Patient: Yeah, they're really diffuse and have been bothering me for a while now. Doctor: I see. We performed a fluoroscopic-guided lumbar puncture to help evaluate your condition. The initial pressure was 5 mmHg by fluid-coupled measurements and 11.5 cm of H2O by fluid column method. We removed a total of 10 cc of clear CSF. The final pressure was 2 mmHg by fluid-coupled measurements and 3.5 cm of H2O by fluid column method. After the puncture, did you experience any changes in your headache? Patient: Yes, actually. I developed a different headache that got worse when I was upright. Doctor: I understand. On a scale of 1 to 10, how severe would you rate this new headache? Patient: I'd say it was an 8 out of 10. It was really bad, and I also had nausea and vomiting. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. It seems your headache was persistent for 4 days and didn't improve with steroids, caffeine infusion, or hydrocodone-acetaminophen treatment. We conducted a magnetic resonance imaging with gadolinium enhancement to further assess your condition. The results showed cerebellar tonsils descending through the foramen magnum, slit ventricles, and enhancement of the dura. Patient: Oh, that sounds serious. Doctor: It's a significant finding, but we proceeded with an epidural injection of whole blood to address your symptoms. How did you feel after the procedure? Patient: I felt much better! The headaches completely went away, and I'd rate them as 0 out of 10 now. Doctor: That's great to hear. Were you able to ambulate without any difficulty after the treatment? Patient: Yes, I didn't have any trouble walking around. Doctor: That's excellent. It appears that the epidural injection was effective in resolving your headaches. Please continue to monitor your symptoms and contact us if you experience any changes or concerns. Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.

Your lungs were clear to auscultation, and there was no evidence of infection or blood loss. We started you on anticoagulation for pulmonary embolism. Do you remember if you had a CT chest done? Doctor: Right, so instead they did a ventilation/perfusion scan, or V/Q scan, which showed intermediate probability for pulmonary thromboembolism. We decided to continue your anticoagulation. However, you still had persistent tachycardia, and blood tests showed hypocalcemia at 6.8-7.9 mg/dL and hypokalemia at 3.2-3.4 mEQ/L, but your thyroid function was normal. Patient: Oh, I didn't know that. Doctor: We also found that your 25-hydroxyvitamin D test was low at 6 ng/ml, and your intact parathyroid hormone was elevated at 85.1 pg/ml. As a result, we put you on metoprolol 50 mg twice daily and continued intravenous hydration with electrolyte supplementation. We eventually did a CT chest which confirmed the presence of old embolism and showed a 1.1 cm nodule in your left upper lobe. Patient: So, what's the plan now? Doctor: We've consulted endocrinology for your persistent tachycardia with relatively stable blood pressure. You also had spikes of temperature for two days, so we started you on Tamiflu and Rocephin while waiting for blood culture results. Patient: Okay, I understand. But I really want to be discharged and go home.

document: Doctor: Hello, I understand you were admitted to our hospital last month with left quadrant abdominal pain and weight loss for more than 6 months. Can you tell me more about your symptoms? Patient: Yes, the pain gets worse after eating, and I also experience abdominal distension, belching, and reduced flatus. Doctor: Have you tried any treatments for these symptoms before coming here? Patient: I was taking some traditional Chinese medicine that temporarily relieved the symptoms. Doctor: I see. Do you have any medical history we should know about? Patient: Yes, I have a history of hypertension, but my control has been poor. Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. It looks like you underwent a colonoscopy examination in a local hospital. What were the results of that examination? Patient: They verbally reported no pathologic findings. Doctor: Alright, during your physical examination here, we found mesogastric tenderness and an enlarged spleen. Your blood laboratory examination reported only mild hypokalemia, and your urinary and stool reports were normal. Enhanced computerized tomography showed splenomegaly, jejunal wall edema, narrowed lumen, enlarged lymph nodes, mesenteric edema, atrophy of the right liver lobe, hypertrophy of the left and caudate lobes, calcification, and periportal fibrosis. These signs are compatible with hepatic schistosomiasis. Patient: Oh, that sounds serious. Doctor: Yes, it is a condition that needs attention. During the double balloon enteroscopy, we noticed that your blood pressure was not stable, so we couldn't reexamine the colon. The upper enteroscopy showed an ulcer 150 cm distal to the Treitz ligament, measuring 3.0 x 2.0 cm. The ulcer had a white coating and peripheral mucosal hyperemia, occupying 2/3 of the lumen, making it difficult for the endoscope to pass through. We took four biopsies from the ulcer, and 20 cm proximal from the ulcer, we found many scattered irregular ulcers, from which we took two biopsies. Patient: What did the histopathological examination reveal? Doctor: The examination reported chronic jejunal inflammation

The symptoms have persisted for over six months. The patient has a history of hypertension with poor control and has used traditional Chinese medicine for symptom relief. No pathologic findings were reported from a previous colonoscopy. Objective: Physical examination revealed mesogastric tenderness and splenomegaly. Laboratory tests showed mild hypokalemia; urinary and stool reports were normal. Enhanced CT indicated splenomegaly, jejunal wall edema, narrowed lumen, enlarged lymph nodes, mesenteric edema, atrophy of the right liver lobe, hypertrophy of the left and caudate lobes, calcification, and periportal fibrosis, suggesting hepatic schistosomiasis. Double balloon enteroscopy was limited due to unstable blood pressure; however, upper enteroscopy revealed a significant ulcer in the jejunum and multiple scattered irregular ulcers

document: Doctor: Hello, I see that you've been referred to our hospital due to a mass that was incidentally discovered in your right kidney. Is that correct? Patient: Yes, that's right. Doctor: The mass is 16-mm in size and located in the anterior medial position of your kidney. We performed a renal biopsy, which confirmed that it's renal cell carcinoma, a type of kidney cancer. Patient: Oh no, that's terrible. Doctor: I understand your concern. We have a treatment plan to address this issue. We placed a hook wire in the tumor with the help of an interventional radiologist and CT guidance. Patient: What's the purpose of that? Doctor: The hook wire helps us localize the tumor during surgery. It's a technique we use for nonpalpable breast lesions to facilitate intraoperative localization. We will perform a partial nephrectomy to remove the tumor. Patient: How does the surgery work? Doctor: You will be placed in a modified left lateral decubitus position, and we will establish pneumoperitoneum. Trocars will be placed to access your abdomen. We will mobilize your bowel medially and develop the plane between the anterior Gerota's fascia and the posterior mesocolon. Patient: Okay, and then? Doctor: Your kidney will be mobilized within Gerota's fascia. We will locate the hook wire and clamp the renal artery with a bulldog. The renal capsule will be resected using scissors under warm ischemia, which will take about 25 minutes. Patient: How will you stop the bleeding? Doctor: Hemostasis will be achieved using a combination of cautery, hemostatic agents, and suturing. We will use sutures preloaded with clips to secure a suture line, allowing for lateral compression perpendicular to the renal capsule. Patient: What will the results be like? Doctor: The histopathology report confirmed clear-cell renal carcinoma with negative surgical margins. According to the TNM 2017 classification, it's stage pT1a. Patient: What does that mean for me? Doctor: It means that the cancer is in its early stage and we were able to remove it completely. We will continue to monitor your condition, but the pro

document: Doctor: Hi there, I see you're a 37-year-old female indicated for IVF due to bilateral tubal factors. We initiated the ovulation induction on day 2 of your menstrual cycle. How have you been feeling since then? Patient: Well, I traveled to So Paulo on business with my mother and sister one day after starting the treatment. I took the medications with me, but I noticed some changes in my body. Doctor: Can you tell me more about these changes? Patient: Sure. I returned and underwent an ultrasound on day 5 of the treatment, and I noticed a skin rash on my trunk, spreading to my limbs. My mother and sister reported the same symptoms too. Doctor: I see. Have you experienced any other symptoms, such as fever or pain? Patient: Yes, my temperature was 37oC, and I had mild low back pain and insignificant joint pain. Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. We did a complete blood count and it did not show any changes in your platelets and leukocytes. We also performed a blood test for ZIKV using a reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) for both you and your husband. Patient: That's good to know. What's next in the treatment? Doctor: We proceeded with the oocyte aspiration at the clinic's expense, and we were able to retrieve seven MII stage oocytes. We also collected your follicular fluid and cumulus cells, as well as your husband's semen, for further study. Patient: I see. Is there anything else I need to be aware of? Doctor: This is a single-patient case report at our private IVF center. Our Institutional Review Board (IRB) does not consider it as human subjects research, so no IRB approval was needed. However, we made sure to get informed written consent from both you and your husband. Patient: Okay, thank you for explaining that. What are the next steps for us? Doctor: We will continue to monitor your progress and keep you informed of any developments. Please continue to take your medications as prescribed and let us know if you experience any further symptoms or side effects. Patient: Alright, thank you for keeping us informed and guiding us through this process. Doctor: You're welcome

We conducted a punch biopsy and the histological examination revealed tumor cells with enlarged nucleoli and clear cytoplasm arranged in trabecular cords and glandular arrays, consistent with metastatic HCC. The histological examination of the specimen revealed diffuse sheets of monomorphous plasmacytoid cells with abundant eosinophilic finely granular cytoplasm and eccentric nuclei. We also observed occasional binucleated and pleomorphic cells with giant nuclei and prominent nucleoli, as well as mitotic figures. Patient: What does that mean? Doctor: These findings indicate that there is no amyloid deposition. Immunohistochemically, the plasma cells were diffusely immunoreactive for  light chain and IgG. This

document: Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today? Patient: Hi, I've got some redness in my right eye and I saw a worm moving in my left eye. Doctor: I see. Have you had any exposure to rural streams during your childhood? Patient: Yes, I used to play in them when I was a kid. Doctor: Alright, let's perform an ocular examination to check your visual acuity and look for any other findings. *After examination* Doctor: Your visual acuity is 6/5 in both eyes, which is normal. I found a temporal subconjunctival hemorrhage in your right eye, but the worm in your left eye is no longer present. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: I'll reassure you that this is not a major issue. However, if you see the worm again, please come back to the clinic. Patient: Sure, thanks. *Eleven months later* Patient: Hi again, I saw the worm in my left eye and I've been experiencing recurrent redness and a feeling of something moving in that eye. I also have generalized body itching, which gets worse at night. Doctor: Alright, let's examine your eye again. *After examination* Doctor: I found a mobile worm in the temporal subconjunctival area of your left eye, which soon migrated to the superior bulbar conjunctiva. Patient: Oh no, what do we do? Doctor: We will perform a conjunctival incision to extract the worm using forceps and repair the wound. *After the procedure* Doctor: The worm has been successfully removed. Histology confirmed it as an adult Loa loa. We've also done a blood work up, which showed negative results for microfilaria but positive eosinophilia at 44.4%. Patient: What does that mean? Doctor: It means that there's an elevated level of eosinophils in your blood, which can be associated with a parasitic infection. We will treat you with oral Albendazole to address this issue. Patient: Alright, thanks for your help.

document: Doctor: Hello, I understand you were referred to our Veterinary Teaching Hospital at CEU Cardenal Herrera University because your French bulldog has a corneal mass on the right eye that has been enlarging over a 2-month period. Is that correct? Patient: Yes, that's right. He's a 7-year-old male and had a complete excision of the third eyelid gland 5 years ago. Doctor: I see. And did he develop any complications after that surgery? Patient: Yes, he developed keratoconjunctivitis sicca, which we've been controlling with cyclosporine eye drops and artificial tears. Doctor: That's good to hear. Now, let's proceed with the examination. I noticed an exophytic pink to white gelatinous mass occupying about 70% of the central cornea on his right eye (Fig. a). His dazzle reflex seems inconsistent, and his menace response is negative. I'll perform a fluorescein staining to check for any corneal damage. Patient: Alright, what did you find? Doctor: The fluorescein staining was negative. I also conducted a slit lamp biomicroscopy examination, which showed a severe increase in corneal thickness, pigment deposit, and superficial vascularization. The mass seems to be infiltrating the corneal stroma. Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good. Doctor: We also performed a Schirmer tear test-1 and measured the intraocular pressure by applanation tonometry. Both of these tests were within normal limits. However, we couldn't perform an indirect ophthalmoscopy. Patient: And what about his left eye? Doctor: The ophthalmic exam of the left eye was unremarkable, and no abnormalities were observed on the physical examination. Patient: So, what's the diagnosis for his right eye? Doctor: At this time, we suspect it may be corneal neoplasia. Other differential diagnoses include granulation tissue and a chronic inflammatory process. To confirm the diagnosis, we performed an excisional superficial keratectomy under general anesthesia. Patient: What did you find from that procedure? Doctor: The histological findings were consistent with corneal carcinoma.

Schirmer tear test-1 and measured intraocular pressure by applanation tonometry, suggesting ophthalmic examination was not normal limits.

document: Doctor: Hello, I see from your history that you have osteoarthritis and hypothyroidism. What brings you in today? Patient: Hi, doc. I noticed a rapidly growing lesion near my left eye about 3 weeks ago, and it's been growing ever since. My primary care physician referred me to you. Doctor: I see. Let's take a look at the lesion. Upon examination, it appears to be a medial orbital mass causing ectropion of the lower eyelid and symptomatic epiphora. We should perform a CT scan of the orbits to further investigate this lesion. Patient: Alright, doc. What did the CT scan results show? Doctor: The CT scan showed a 2.0  1.6  1.0 cm nonenhancing intraorbital soft tissue lesion abutting the nasal lacrimal duct, lateral and inferior to the globe, without definite osseous remodeling. There is no thickening of the lateral rectus muscle or inflammation. There is a moderate lateral displacement of the intraocular structures, but the globe is intact. Patient: Oh, I see. What's the next step, doc? Doctor: We performed an anterior orbitotomy with biopsy 4 days after your presentation. The pathology was initially read as positive for intermediate grade epithelioid carcinoma, but after an outside consultation, the diagnosis was edited to epithelioid sarcoma with rhabdoid features (proximal type). Patient: What does that mean, exactly? Doctor: Immunohistochemical stains revealed the tumor to be AE1/AE3 strong positive, GATA3 strong positive, vimentin strong positive, EMA focal positive, calponin focal positive, and a series of other markers were negative. This helps us better understand the nature of the tumor. Patient: Considering my age and the tumor's histology, what are my treatment options? Doctor: Due to your age and the tumor histology, chemotherapy is not recommended by medical oncology. We completed your staging workup with a soft tissue neck CT, which showed no evidence of abnormal lymph nodes. After a biopsy, we diagnosed you with nodular sclerosis Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL). Patient: Oh, that sounds serious. Doctor: It is a type of cancer, but don't worry. We will do our best to help you. We also performed a fetal ultrasound screening and it showed that your baby is developing normally. Patient: That's a relief. What's the plan for my treatment? document: Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today? Patient: Hi, I've had a mass on my anterior abdominal wall for about a year now. It's been gradually increasing in size and causing me discomfort. Doctor: I see. Have you noticed any changes in the mass or your symptoms during certain times, such as during your menstrual cycle? Patient: Yes, it gets worse during my menses. The mass seems to get bigger and the pain becomes more intense. Doctor: Okay, thank you for sharing that. Have you had any surgeries in the past, specifically in the abdominal area? Patient: I had a caesarean section six years ago, but that's it. Doctor: Alright. I would like to perform a physical examination to get a better understanding of the mass. Patient: Sure, go ahead. Doctor: *Examines the patient* I can feel a circumscribed mass measuring approximately 6 cms in diameter in the infraumbilical region to the left of the midline. The mobility of the swelling seems to be restricted when you contract your muscles, which may suggest infiltration of the underlying musculoaponeurotic structures. Patient: What does that mean, exactly? Doctor: It means the mass may be affecting the muscles and tissues beneath the skin. We will need to conduct some laboratory investigations and a CT scan to get a clearer picture. Patient: Okay, let's do it. *After the tests* Doctor: The laboratory results are within normal limits, and the CT scan revealed a contrast-enhancing lesion in the subcutaneous tissues, infiltrating the underlying musculoaponeurotic structures. This is highly suggestive of an abdominal wall endometrioma. Patient: So, what's the next step for me? Doctor: The best course of action would be surgical resection. We would remove the endometrioma along with a portion of the underlying aponeurosis and rectus abdominis muscle. Patient: And after that? Doctor: We will place a polypropylene mesh over the defect created by the resection and fix it to the anterior rectus sheath with nonabsorbable sutures. This will help to reinforce the area and promote healing. Patient: What can I expect after the surgery? Doctor: The
