document: Doctor: Hello, I'm Dr. Smith. How can I help you today? Patient: Hi, Doctor. I was diagnosed with rectal adenocarcinoma back in 2013. I had a biopsy done after an endoscopic control examination. I was treated with radio adjuvant chemotherapy and surgery. I'm here for a follow-up appointment. Doctor: I see. How have you been feeling since your treatments? Patient: I've been feeling pretty good, actually. The combination of treatments led to a complete response, and there were no residual cancer areas or lymph node involvement documented on the surgical piece. Doctor: That's great to hear. Let's discuss your recent check-up. In 2018, during your regular oncological follow-up, a subpleural pulmonary nodule was detected in the lower lobe of your left lung. It measured about 15x10 mm. Considering your clinical history, general conditions, and the localization of the lesion, a surgical resection of the lung was performed. Do you remember that? Patient: Yes, I do. Doctor: On the macroscopic exam of the sample, physicians observed a neoformation measuring 1.9x1.5x0.6 cm, which was whitish, solid, with irregular but well-defined margins. It was 0.6 cm away from the surgical suture and 0.1 cm from the visceral pleura. The histologic examination demonstrated an epitheliomorphic neoplasm with acinar differentiation. Patient: Hmm, what does that mean? Doctor: It means that the tumor cells were positive for cytokeratin 20 (CK20) and had scattered positivity for caudal type homeobox 2 (CDX2). They were also strongly and diffusely positive for TTF-1. However, the tumor cells were negative for CK7 and Napsin A. A retrospective review of your previous primary tumor tissue showed similar histologic findings with TTF-1 positivity. Patient: So, what's the diagnosis? Doctor: Based on the positivity for CK20 and CDX2, and the negative results for CK7 and Napsin A, along with the morphology of the lesion, the diagnosis is metastasis from TTF1-positive primary colorectal adeno

document: Doctor: Hello, I wanted to discuss the case of the two-year-old wild female cheetah from the temporary holding facility that developed seizures, raised tail, and arched back in November 2008. Patient's Family: Yes, we remember. She passed away despite the treatment. Doctor: That's correct. After her passing, she was submitted to the National Zoological Gardens of South Africa for a necropsy examination. She was part of a project to re-establish cheetah populations in protected, fenced reserves. The goal was to ensure the animals were fit and able to hunt effectively before being released. Patient's Family: Yes, we know they went through a re-wilding process in a 1 ha enclosure initially. Doctor: Exactly. While in the enclosure, antelope and birds were shot on the reserve as cheetah food. Once the cheetahs were able to open and feed off a full carcass, they were released from the enclosure and monitored intensively. The management, handling, and feeding schedules were consistent among the female and three males. Unfortunately, the female was the only mortality. Patient's Family: That's so sad. What did the necropsy reveal? Doctor: Due to delayed presentation, tissue preservation in the cheetah was poor. We examined a representative sample of all tissues except the eye and spinal cord. Both macroscopic and histological features were non-specific and non-diagnostic. Patient's Family: Were there any other significant findings? Doctor: Yes, we found four lead pellet fragments of less than one millimeter diameter in the cheetah's stomach. Tissue lead concentrations of 15.6 ppm and 17 ppm (wet weight) for kidney and liver respectively were determined at the Onderstepoort Veterinary Institute Toxicology Department using atomic absorption spectrophotometry. These findings were highly suggestive of lead poisoning. Patient's Family: How did you confirm it was lead poisoning? Doctor: Organ samples and blanks were acid digested and compared with standard lead solutions. The results confirmed the diagnosis of lead poisoning. Patient's Family: Oh no, that's terrible. Thank you for letting us

Doctor: Have you been eating a balanced diet and drinking moderately? Patient: Yes, I have been. Doctor: Is there any family history of similar symptoms? Patient: No, there's no family history of this. Doctor: Alright. We conducted a neurological examination and found no disturbance of consciousness or cranial nerve abnormalities. No muscle weakness was present in your neck or upper extremities, but mild weakness was evident in the lower limbs. Have you experienced any severe pain during daily physical activities? document: Doctor: Hi, I see that you were admitted to our hospital with a history of hemoptysis, shortness of breath, and fever for the past two weeks. Can you tell me more about your symptoms? Patient: Yeah, I've been feeling really tired and I've been having night sweats. My knees have been hurting on both sides, and I noticed a rash on my back and chest. Doctor: I understand. And, prior to this admission, did you experience any other symptoms? Patient: About two months ago, I started having a nonproductive cough, and I felt weak all over with muscle pain. Doctor: Okay, and were you prescribed any medications for these musculoskeletal symptoms? Patient: Yes, my primary care doctor gave me prednisone 20 mg daily for five days, but it didn't help. Doctor: Alright. At the time of admission, we recorded your blood pressure to be 130/69 mmHg, heart rate at 99 bpm, temperature at 37.8°C (100°F), and a respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute. We also found bilateral diffuse rales on chest auscultation and a morbilliform rash on your back and upper chest. We conducted some laboratory studies to further investigate your condition. Patient: What did those tests show? Doctor: Your white blood cell count was 13.2  103/ml, erythrocyte sedimentation rate was 122 mm/hour, which is significantly higher than the reference rate of 20 mm/hour. Your hemoglobin was 10.4 g/dl, serum creatinine was 1.48 mg/dl, which is above the reference range of 0.61.1 mg/dl, and your glomerular filtration rate was 57 ml/min/1.73 m2, which is lower than the reference rate of >90 ml/min. The urinalysis showed proteinuria and hematuria with few red blood cell casts. Patient: That doesn't sound good. What does that mean? Doctor: These results indicate some issues with your kidneys and increased inflammation in your body. We also conducted a chest radiograph that demonstrated diffuse nodular reticular interstitial opacities and right upper lobe cavitation.

document: Doctor: Hello, I'm Dr. Smith. I understand you were diagnosed with stage IV transverse colon cancer and have undergone chemotherapy treatments in another hospital. Can you tell me about your experience with the treatments so far? Patient: Yes, I started with the mFOLFOX6 therapy, which included modified fluorouracil, leucovorin, and oxaliplatin, along with bevacizumab, an anti-VEGF-A antibody. I had 23 courses of that over a year, and it didn't cause many side effects. Doctor: I see. However, your cancer has been categorized as progressive disease after that treatment. So, what was the next course of action? Patient: My doctors started me on secondary therapy, which was FOLFIRI, with fluorouracil, leucovorin, and irinotecan, plus ramucirumab, an anti-VEGFR2 antibody. Doctor: And how did your body respond to that treatment? Patient: After 2 courses of the therapy, I started developing anasarca and nephrotic syndrome. Doctor: I see you were referred to our nephrology clinic and admitted to our hospital on day 44 after the treatment. Let's discuss your blood test results. You had thrombocytopenia with platelets at 57,000/L, slight normocytic anemia with hemoglobin at 11.3 g/dL, mild hypoalbuminemia at 3.0 g/dL, and a mild increase in lactate dehydrogenase level at 433 IU/L. Schistocytes were not found in your peripheral blood smear, and your haptoglobin level was not measured. Your urinary protein was 5.1 g/g-creatinine, and dysmorphic erythrocytes were found in your urine. Patient: Hmm, that sounds concerning. What does it all mean? Doctor: A renal biopsy was performed on day 45, which showed fibrin thrombi within capillary loops, mesangiolysis, and double contour of the basement membrane of glomeruli. document: Doctor: Hello, it's nice to meet you. Can you please tell me about your medical history and any recent symptoms you've been experiencing? Patient: Hi, I am a 63-year-old female, a former smoker. I have hypothyroidism, hypertension, and dyslipidemia. Back in 2001, I had some generalized xanthomatous skin lesions. Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. Have you been experiencing any pain or discomfort lately? Patient: Yes, I had abdominal pain back in 2004, and that's when my doctor suggested a computed tomography (CT) scan of my upper abdomen. Doctor: I see. Did they use contrast for the CT scan? Patient: Yes, they did. Doctor: The CT scan with contrast demonstrated hypoattenuating tissue involving the abdominal aorta and its branches. This led to a discrete segmental narrowing of some vessels, characterized by narrowing of the aorta in the emergence region of the renal arteries and the left subclavian artery. Did they perform a tissue biopsy after the scan? Patient: Yes, they took a biopsy, and it showed the presence of a pseudotumor. Doctor: That biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of Erdheim-Chester Disease (ECD). Did they also perform an 18-FDG PET-CT scan to assess the extent of the disease? Patient: Yes, they did. Doctor: The FDG PET-CT showed signs of retroperitoneal fibrosis involving the abdominal aorta immediately above and at the emergence region of the renal arteries. There was also infiltrative tissue surrounding the aortic arch, descending aorta, and left common iliac artery. Did they check for any cardiac involvement? Patient: They did a cardiac MRI, and it showed normal-sized chambers and preserved systolic function. Doctor: That's good to hear. The cardiac MRI ruled out any cardiac involvement, which is a positive sign. It's essential to keep monitoring your condition and manage your hypothyroidism, hypertension, and dyslipidemia to prevent any complications. Make sure to follow up with your doctor regularly and report any new or worsening symptoms. Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I

document: Doctor: Hello, I understand you're a 12-year-old patient who had a fall recently. Can you tell me more about the fall? Patient: Yeah, I fell from a height of around 2 meters and landed on my outstretched hand. Doctor: I see. Were there any obvious deformities or other issues after the fall? Patient: My elbow joint looked really weird and bent, but the skin wasn't broken or anything. Doctor: Thank you for the information. After reviewing your radiographs, it seems that you have a closed fracture-dislocation involving the olecranon process, a Salter-Harris type I fracture of the radial neck, and a posterior dislocation of the elbow joint. Patient: Oh no, that sounds serious. What do we do now? Doctor: We performed an open reduction and internal fixation of the fracture the following day. You were under general anesthesia and in the lateral position during the procedure. We approached your elbow posteriorly and used a 1.6-mm K-wire to hold the radial head in place. The olecranon was reduced under direct vision and held with a tension band using two 1.6-mm K-wires. Patient: I see. So, what happened after the surgery? Doctor: Postoperatively, we protected your elbow using an above-elbow slab for three weeks. After that, we started both active and passive range of motion exercises. Patient: And how did my elbow heal after that? Doctor: The fracture healed uneventfully, and within six weeks of fixation, you had a complete range of motion of 30-130 degrees at the elbow joint. Patient: That's great to hear! Did anything else need to be done? Doctor: Yes, we removed the implant after six months. You are now completely asymptomatic with a full range of flexion, extension, supination, and pronation, along with evidence of bony union. Patient: Wow, thank you so much, Doctor! I'm so glad to be feeling better and back to normal.
prediction: Subjective: The patient is a 12-year-old who recently fell from around 2 meters and landed on his outstretched hand. He has been diagnosed with an open fracture-dislocation involving the olecranon process, Salter-Harris type I fracture, and posterior dislocation of the elbow joint. Postoperatively, the patient was under general anesthesia and in lateral position during the surgery. Objective: Radiographs indicate he has refractory fractures, including an above-elbow slab for three weeks, followed by an active and passive range of motion of 30-130 degrees, with flexion, extension, supination and pronation, along with evidence of bony union. After six weeks of fixation the fracture healed unevently. The radial head was reduced under direct vision and held with tension band using two 1.6-mm K-wires. During the procedure, his elbow was held by 1.4- mm k- wires for the upper elbow slabs and an upper arm slab. Following the operation, there was no obvious deformities or other issues.
summarization: Subjective: The patient is a 12-year-old who experienced a fall from a height of approximately 2 meters, landing on an outstretched hand. The patient reported an abnormal appearance of the elbow joint but no skin breach. The chief complaint was the deformity and pain in the elbow. Objective: Examination and radiographs revealed a closed fracture-dislocation of the olecranon process, a Salter-Harris type I fracture of the radial neck, and a posterior dislocation of the elbow joint. Surgical intervention involved open reduction and internal fixation using a 1.6-mm K-wire for the radial head and a tension band for the olecranon. Postoperative protection included an above-elbow slab for three weeks, followed by range of motion exercises. Six weeks post-fixation, the patient achieved a complete range of motion (30-130 degrees). The implant was removed after six months, confirming full functional recovery and bony union. Assessment: The primary diagnosis was a closed fracture-dislocation of the elbow with associated Salter-Harris type I fracture of the radial neck

document: Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today? Patient: Hi, I've been having a fever and a headache for about a month now, and I've been vomiting too. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Let me ask you a few questions to better understand your situation. Have you been evaluated for immune-suppressed states like diabetes mellitus, AIDS, and hepatitis B and C virus infections? Patient: Yes, I've been tested for all of those, and the results came back negative. Doctor: Okay, that's good to know. Based on your symptoms of fever and headache, I'm considering a provisional diagnosis of meningoencephalitis. I'll order a CT brain scan with contrast to further investigate your condition. Patient: Alright, thank you. Doctor: The CT brain scan with contrast has shown multiple ring-enhancing lesions. We also performed an MRI brain spectroscopy, which revealed ring-enhancing lesions with surrounding oedema. These lesions are reported to be tuberculomas based on the imaging findings and MRI spectroscopy findings. Patient: Oh! What does that mean? Doctor: Tuberculomas are masses that can develop in the brain due to a tuberculosis infection. To further investigate, we performed a CT thorax scan with administration of intravenous contrast. The scan showed consolidation with cavitation in your left upper lobe and fibrosing mediastinitis. There was also soft tissue extension along the left hilum, narrowing the left pulmonary vessels and left bronchus. Enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes were seen as well. Patient: That sounds serious. What's the next step? Doctor: Given the brain lesions and lung findings, we suspected tuberculosis. So, we performed a CT-guided biopsy of the thick-walled cavity. The histopathological and microbiological findings showed features of cryptococcus pneumonia. Patient: What does that mean for my treatment? Doctor: We've started you on antifungal therapy to treat the cryptococcus pneumonia. This should help you improve symptomatically. Patient: Okay, thank you for explaining everything. I'm glad we found out what

Microbiology revealed features of cryptococcus pneumonia.

Objective: A CT brain scan with contrast and MRI brain spectroscopy identified multiple ring-enhancing lesions with surrounding edema, suggestive of tuberculomas. A CT thorax scan revealed consolidation with cavitation in the left upper lobe, fibrosing mediastinitis, soft tissue extension along the left hilum, narrowing of the left pulmonary vessels and left bronchus, and enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes. A CT-guided biopsy of the thick-walled cavity indicated features of cryptococcus pneumonia. Assessment: The primary diagnosis is cryptococcus pneumonia, evidenced by histopathological and microbiological findings, in the context of central nervous system involvement suggested by imaging. Differential diagnosis initially included tuberculosis due to the pulmonary and brain findings, but this was ruled out with biopsy results.

Have you experienced any eye pain, tearing, redness, hearing loss, difficulty swallowing, or weakness or numbness in your extremities? Patient: No, none of those symptoms. Doctor: Alright, are you able to understand and express words without any difficulty? Patient: Yes, I can. Doctor: Have you had any headache, gait problems, falls, or recent illness? Do you have a prior history of stroke or seizures? Patient: No, I haven't had any of those. Doctor: What about your past medical history? Do you have any existing conditions? Patient: Yeah, I have hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, and multiple myeloma. Doctor: Are you currently on any medications for those conditions? Patient: Yes, I'm on chemotherapy with ixazomib, acyclovir prophylaxis, and a daily aspirin. Doctor: Thank you for the information. Let's check your vital signs and perform a physical examination. [After examination] Doctor: Your vital signs are unremarkable, but the examination showed lower facial muscle weakness with no difficulty in closing your left eye. Your National Institutes of Health stroke scale is two for facial weakness and dysarthria. We'll need to do some blood work to further investigate. [After blood work] Doctor: Your blood work shows mild anemia and normal serum calcium. Your coagulation workup is unremarkable as well. We'll need to perform a non-contrast computerized tomography (CT) of your head to get a better understanding of what's happening. [After CT] Doctor: The CT results show acute intraparenchymal hemorrhage in the right parietal region with global cerebral atrophy. We'll also perform a CT angiogram of your head and neck to further investigate. [After CT angiogram] Doctor: The CT angiogram results are unremarkable. However, on the second day, you were unable to close your left eye with Bell's phenomenon. We

document: Doctor: Hello, I understand you were hospitalized recently due to a motorcycle crash. Can you tell me about any symptoms you've been experiencing? Patient: Yeah, I suffered some blunt chest and abdominal trauma, and I also had a concussion, but I didn't lose consciousness. Doctor: I see. It's good to know that you were conscious. Your Glasgow Coma Scale score was 15, which means you were alert and responsive. You were also hemodynamically stable when you arrived at the hospital. Patient: That's a relief to hear. How did my abdomen feel when I got here? Doctor: Your abdomen was soft, nondistended, and nontender to palpation with no guarding. That's a good sign. We also conducted some lab tests to check your blood levels. Patient: What were the results of the lab tests? Doctor: Your labs were significant for a hemoglobin count of 14.2 g/dL, which is within the normal range of 13.517.5 g/dL. Your white blood count was 11.8 1000/L, slightly higher than the normal range of 4.511 1000/L, and your lactate level was 1.7 mmol/L, which is also within the normal range of 0.72.1 mmol/L. These levels remained stable throughout your hospital course. Patient: Okay, so what happened next? Doctor: We performed an initial intravenous contrast-enhanced CT scan of your abdomen and pelvis 10 minutes after you arrived. The CT scan was interpreted by a radiology resident 15 minutes later, and a board-certified emergency radiologist completed the final interpretation in an additional 1 hour and 25 minutes. Patient: What did the CT scan show? Doctor: The initial CT interpretation indicated nonspecific wall thickening of the proximal jejunum, and occult small bowel injury could not be excluded. Given these findings, we ordered a repeat CT of the abdomen and pelvis with intravenous and oral contrast as per our institution's standard protocol for evaluation of possible occult bowel injury in blunt abdominal trauma. Patient: When was the follow-up CT performed? Doctor: The follow-up CT was performed after midnight, 8 hours after the initial CT. It demonstrated trace pneumoperitoneum, possibly originating

Laboratory tests were significant for hemoglobin of 14.2 g/dL, within the normal range of 13.517.5, white blood count was 11.8 1000/L and lactate level was 1.7 mmol/L. Initial CT scan indicated nonspecific wall thickening of the proximal jejunum and occult small bowel injury could not be excluded. The follow-up CT showed trace pneumoperitoneum, possibly originating from the motorcycle accident. Blood levels were stable throughout the hospital course. Initially intravenous contrast-enhanced CT of abdomen and pelvis was performed after midnight, 8 hours after the initial CT revealed traces of tracheopoetic pulmonary artery, indicating the patient's symptoms were positive for symptomatic thrombosis, as indicated by an intravascular and oral contrast with intravennous /oral contrast. A repeat CT was conducted after
summarization: Subjective: The patient reports experiencing blunt chest and abdominal trauma and a concussion without loss of consciousness following a motorcycle crash. The patient was alert and responsive with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 15 upon hospital arrival. Objective: Physical examination revealed a soft, nondistended, and nontender abdomen with no guarding. Initial lab tests showed a hemoglobin level of 14.2 g/dL (normal range: 13.517.5 g/dL), a slightly elevated white blood count of 11.8 1000/L (normal range: 4.511 1000/L), and a normal lactate level of 1.7 mmol/L (normal range: 0.72.1 mmol/L). Initial CT scan indicated nonspecific wall thickening of the proximal jejunum. A follow-up CT scan demonstrated trace pneumoperitoneum, possibly originating from the splenic flexure of the colon, without evidence of extravasation of oral contrast. Assessment: The primary diagnosis is blunt abdominal trauma with a possible occult small bowel injury, as suggested by initial imaging findings and subsequent detection

document: Doctor: Hello, I see you're a 12-year-old boy. Can you tell me what symptoms you've been experiencing recently? Patient: Yeah, I've been feeling general malaise, drowsiness, appetite loss, nausea, and discomfort in my abdomen. My urine has also been darker than usual for the past two days. Doctor: I understand. It seems you were admitted to the Clinic of Infectious Diseases at St. George University Hospital in Bulgaria. When you arrived, did they notice any changes in your skin or eyes? Patient: Yes, they said my skin and conjunctivas were mildly jaundiced. Doctor: Okay. On admission, were you able to walk and move around normally? Patient: Yeah, I was ambulatory, and they didn't find any neurological symptoms at first. Doctor: I see. Did your jaundice worsen, or did you experience any other symptoms after being admitted? Patient: Yes, the jaundice got worse, and my malaise progressed. I also had abdominal pain, headache, and pain in the muscles of my lower extremities. Doctor: Were you running a fever, or were you conscious during this time? Patient: No, I was afebrile and conscious. Doctor: Thank you for the information. It seems that between the 2nd and 14th day after admission, a neurological examination revealed some issues. Can you tell me more about that? Patient: Sure. They found absent Achilles and knee-jerk reflexes, diminished brachioradialis reflex, and absent abdominal and cremasteric reflexes. They also said I had moderately decreased muscle power in my upper extremities and more pronounced power loss in my lower extremities. document: Doctor: Hi there, I understand your 1-year old mixed-breed dog has been referred to me due to an issue with her left eye. Can you please tell me more about the problem? Patient: Yes, she's been having this mucopurulent discharge from her left eye for about 14 days now. It started suddenly after we took her for a walk in a meadow. Doctor: I see. Did you notice any changes in her eye before the discharge started? Patient: No, it was pretty much acute in onset and developed after that walk. Doctor: Thank you for the information. Has your dog received any treatment for this issue so far? Patient: Yes, our previous veterinarian prescribed 0.3% tobramycin eye drops for her. Doctor: How long has she been using the eye drops, and have you noticed any improvement since starting the therapy? Patient: She's been using the drops for some days now, but we haven't seen any ocular improvement during this therapy. Doctor: I understand. Let me perform an ophthalmic examination to get a better understanding of her condition. [After examination] I found an abundant mucopurulent to haemorrhagic discharge and a moderate conjunctival hyperemia in her left eye. I didn't see any other abnormalities in this eye. Her right eye appears to be normal. Patient: What does that mean, doctor? Doctor: Based on the findings, the presumptive diagnosis is that your dog has unilateral dacryocystitis, which is an inflammation of the tear sac, likely due to a foreign body in her left eye. Patient: Oh, I see. What can we do to help her? Doctor: We will need to remove the foreign body and provide appropriate treatment to resolve the inflammation and infection. I will discuss the options with you and provide recommendations for follow-up care. Patient: Thank you, doctor. We really appreciate your help with our dog's eye problem.

The onset was sudden, occurring after a walk in a meadow. No prior changes in the eye were noted before the discharge began. The dog has been treated with 0.3% tobramycin eye drops without observed improvement. Objective: Ophthalmic examination revealed abundant mucopurulent to haemorrhagic discharge and moderate conjunctival hyperemia in the left eye. No other abnormalities were noted in the affected eye, and the right eye appears normal. Assessment: The primary diagnosis is unilateral dacryocystitis, likely secondary to a foreign body in the left eye. The lack of response to tobramycin suggests either an inappropriate treatment for the underlying cause or a resistant infection. Plan: The management plan includes removal of the foreign body from the left eye under sedation or anesthesia. document: Doctor: Hello Mr. Turner, I've been reviewing your case and I wanted to talk to you about your condition. You are a 65-year-old ambulatory diabetic patient with concomitant mental illness and alcoholism. It seems that you've had some difficulty sticking to your diabetic regime in the past. Can you share more about that? Patient: Yeah, I had a tough time managing my diabetes. I guess I just didn't take it seriously enough. Doctor: I understand, Mr. Turner. Over a 21-month period, you had 44 emergency department visits and 27 hospitalizations, with over half of those hospitalizations being in the Intensive Care Unit for diabetic ketoacidosis. It became medically necessary to involve Home-Based Primary Care (HBPC) to help you manage your condition better. How have you been feeling since the HBPC visits started? Patient: Oh, those visits have made a huge difference! I feel much more engaged in my care now, and I'm starting to understand how important it is to manage my diabetes. Doctor: That's great to hear. I see that the HBPC team consulted behavioral health clinicians to help you with your mental health and alcoholism as well. Are you finding their support helpful? Patient: Yes, they've been really helpful. I feel like I'm finally getting the support I need to deal with everything going on in my life. Doctor: I'm glad to hear that, Mr. Turner. I also noticed that you got new glasses to help you read your insulin syringes. Has that made a difference in your ability to manage your diabetes? Patient: Absolutely! I can finally see the markings on the syringes clearly, so I'm more confident in taking the right amount of insulin. Doctor: That's excellent, Mr. Turner. It seems like after the house calls were initiated, your adherence to your diabetic regime and your overall quality of life dramatically improved. In fact, you've only had one hospitalization over the next two years. How do you feel about your progress? Patient: I'm really happy with how things are going. It's been a big change, but I feel like I'm finally in control of my health. Doctor: I'm glad to hear that, Mr. Turner. HBPC

He noted significant improvement in his condition and engagement in care following the initiation of Home-Based Primary Care (HBPC) visits. He expressed that the support from behavioral health clinicians was beneficial and that new glasses improved his ability to administer insulin correctly. Objective: Mr. Turner has a history of 44 emergency department visits and 27 hospitalizations over 21 months, primarily for diabetic ketoacidosis, with over half of these hospitalizations in the Intensive Care Unit. Since the start of HBPC, his hospitalizations reduced significantly, with only one occurrence over the following two years. Assessment: Mr. Turner's primary diagnosis is diabetes mellitus, complicated by mental illness and alcoholism. The introduction of HBPC has led to improved management of his diabetes and overall quality of life. The interdisciplinary approach and additional support for mental health and visual impairment have been crucial in enhancing his adherence to the diabetic regime. Plan: Continue the current HBPC program and maintain regular follow-ups

document: Doctor: Hello, I see you were referred to our department due to a several-week history of right inguinal pain and discomfort in your right femur that worsened with movement. Can you describe the pain and discomfort you've been experiencing? Patient: Yes, the pain in my right groin area has been bothering me for a few weeks now. It gets worse whenever I move, and I also feel some discomfort in my right thigh. Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. We conducted laboratory tests, and your white blood cell count and C-reactive protein levels were normal. We also performed ultrasound and computed tomography examinations, which indicated a vermiform appendix in an inguinal hernia sac. However, there were no remarkable findings of inflammation in the appendix (Fig. a, b). Patient: Oh, I see. So, what's the diagnosis then? Doctor: Based on these findings, we diagnosed you with an Amyand's hernia (AH) without appendicitis. We attempted a reduction of the hernia under ultrasound, but it was unsuccessful. Therefore, we planned a combined totally extraperitoneal (TEP) mesh repair and laparoscopic appendectomy after laparoscopic reduction. Patient: Hmm, okay. What does that procedure involve? Doctor: First, you will be placed in a supine position and undergo general anesthesia by tracheal intubation. We will first perform a laparoscopic transabdominal approach after establishing pneumoperitoneum. A 5-mm direct umbilical trocar and a needle forceps (Endo ReliefTM) will be introduced into the upper right abdominal quadrant to inspect the hernia canal for the absence of appendicitis and reduce the appendix laparoscopically. Patient: Alright. What happens after that? Doctor: During the inspection, we found a 3  2 cm right external inguinal hernia defect with the appendix, but no other intra-abdominal pathology was identified. document: Doctor: Hello, I see that you were admitted to our hospital with the chief complaint of jaundice in your skin and sclera, along with epigastric pain for the past two weeks. Is that correct? Patient: Yes, that's right. The yellowing and pain have been bothering me a lot. Doctor: I understand. We've conducted several examinations to determine the cause, including enhanced abdominal and pelvic CT scans, a chest X-ray, an abdominal ultrasound, tumor markers, liver and renal function tests, and coagulation function tests. Let me go over the results with you. Patient: Okay, please do. Doctor: The CT scans revealed a low-density mass of 4.0 cm in diameter located in the uncinate process of your pancreas. Additionally, your intra- and extra-hepatic bile ducts are obviously dilated, and your pancreatic duct is slightly dilated as well. The non-contrast CT scan showed calcification within the mass, and the contrast CT showed that the enhancement of the tumor is similar to the surrounding normal pancreatic parenchyma. Here's a figure for you to see (Fig.). Patient: Oh, I see. What does that mean? Doctor: It means there's a growth in your pancreas that could be contributing to your symptoms. Now, let's go over your laboratory data. Your white blood cell count, red blood cell count, and hemoglobin levels are within the normal ranges. However, your AFP level is elevated at 71.5 ng/mL, while the normal range is less than 8.1 ng/mL. Patient: Hmm, that doesn't sound good. Doctor: Additionally, your carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is within the normal range at 2.0 ng/mL, but your carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (CA 19-9) is significantly elevated at 437.2 U/mL, with the normal range being 0-37 U/mL. Your aspartate transaminase (AST) and alanine transaminase (ALT) levels are also elevated, at 51 U/L and 151 U/L, respectively. Patient: Wow, that's quite high.

document: Doctor: Hello, S.B. I see that you were prescribed rivaroxaban for atrial fibrillation in the past. Can you tell me more about why you stopped the treatment? Patient: Hi, doctor. I stopped taking rivaroxaban because I saw some television advertisements that raised concerns about the risks. Doctor: I understand your concern. Unfortunately, several months after stopping rivaroxaban therapy, you suffered an ischemic cerebral vascular accident (CVA) which converted to a hemorrhagic stroke 2 days later. That happened 2 years ago, correct? Patient: Yes, that's right. It was a difficult time for me and my family. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. These events resulted in left hemiplegia, which I can see from your medical report. Now, you've been taking warfarin for your atrial fibrillation and have been monitored at your local anticoagulation clinic for about a year, correct? Patient: Yes, doctor. I've been going there for regular checkups and they monitor my international normalized ratio (INR) levels. Doctor: That's good to hear. It seems that during your year of warfarin therapy, you reported regularly to the anticoagulation clinic for INR monitoring, with 5- to 8-week follow-up intervals. Most of the time, your INR remained within the prescribed therapeutic range of 2-3. Is that correct? Patient: Yes, that's correct. Doctor: I also see that you've been suffering from numerous sequelae related to your CVA, and you decided to pursue hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) to improve your clinical status and quality of life. Is that correct? Patient: Yes, I wanted to try something that might help me feel better and improve my quality of life. Doctor: I understand. Now, prior to starting your HBOT, you went to the anticoagulation clinic for a regular follow-up, and it was determined that your INR was elevated at 3.5. During the discussion, your son, who is also your caregiver, mentioned that you would be undergoing 1-hour HBOT sessions, five times a week, for a total duration of 6 weeks. Is that correct? Patient: Yes, that's right. We've been traveling a long distance
prediction: Subjective: The patient was prescribed rivaroxaban for atrial fibrillation in the past and stopped the treatment after seeing television advertisements that raised concerns about the risks. The Patient reported a ischemic cerebral vascular accident (CVA) 2 years ago, which resulted in left hemiplegia 2 days later. During the year of warfarin therapy, the patient reported regularly to the anticoagulation clinic for regular checkups, with 5- to 8-week follow-up intervals. INR was elevated at 3.5, despite frequent observation of the iNR, and remained within the prescribed therapeutic range of 2-3. He has been pursuing hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) to improve clinical status and quality of life. His son, who is also undergoing 1-hour HBOT sessions, five times weekly, for 6 weeks.
summarization: Subjective: Patient S.B., previously on rivaroxaban for atrial fibrillation, discontinued the medication due to concerns raised by television advertisements. Suffered an ischemic stroke that converted to hemorrhagic stroke two years ago, resulting in left hemiplegia. Currently on warfarin, regularly monitored at an anticoagulation clinic with INR mostly within the therapeutic range of 2-3. Experiencing multiple sequelae from CVA and undergoing hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) to improve quality of life. Objective: Patient's INR was elevated at 3.5 prior to starting HBOT and was 3.2 during a recent check, slightly out of the therapeutic range. No bleeding complications noted during the ongoing HBOT treatment, which consists of 1-hour sessions, five times a week for six weeks. Assessment: Primary diagnosis is atrial fibrillation with complications of post-stroke sequelae including left hemiplegia. The patient is currently stable on warfarin therapy with occasional elevated INR levels. Differential diagnosis includes potential bleeding risks associated with elevated INR and HBOT. Plan: Continue current dose of warfar

document: Doctor: Good morning. How can I help you today? Patient: Hi, doctor. I've been experiencing some difficulty swallowing and pain when swallowing for about two months now. I also feel like solid foods are getting stuck in my neck. Doctor: I see. Have you experienced any choking or gagging? Patient: No, I haven't. Doctor: Alright. Have you had any tests or treatments for this issue? Patient: Yes, I had neck ultrasonography at my primary care doctor's office, and they found a 6.1-cm cyst. They thought it was an infection and treated me with antibiotics, but my symptoms didn't improve. Doctor: Okay, thank you for the information. Have you had any other health problems in the past? Patient: Yes, I have a history of hypertension. Doctor: Do you have any other complaints or any history of immunosuppressive disorders like HIV/AIDS, celiac disease, or inflammatory bowel disease? Patient: No, I don't. And I haven't had any nausea, vomiting, fever, chills, gastroesophageal reflux symptoms, or weight loss either. Doctor: Good to know. What about your family history? Is there any history of cancer? Patient: No, my family history is negative for cancer. Doctor: Thank you. I'd like to perform a physical examination now. *After the examination* I found a large, tender, and palpable neck mass. We'll need to run some laboratory tests and imaging studies to investigate further. *After receiving test results* Doctor: Your laboratory studies, including hematology, serum biochemistry, and urine analysis, are all within normal limits. However, the computed tomography (CT) scan of your head and neck showed a 7.3  3.1  6.6-cm mass in your neck, which is inseparable from your cervical esophagus. There is no apparent bone compression. Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good. Doctor: We also performed a barium esophagogram which showed an intact esophageal mucosa, but there is marked narrowing of the cervical part of your esophagus. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy confirmed the tumor

document: Doctor: Hello, I see you have a history of alcohol abuse, and you've presented to the gastroenterology department. What brings you in today? Patient: Hi, I've been suffering from severe epigastric pain and nausea for the past two days. Doctor: I see. Based on your symptoms and your history, I would like to run some laboratory tests to see if there might be any issue with your pancreas. The findings may help us determine if you have pancreatitis or not. Patient: Okay, that makes sense. [After the tests] Doctor: Your laboratory findings were suspicious for pancreatitis, so we decided to proceed with a computed tomography (CT) examination. The CT scan showed an edematous pancreas tail and fluid in the anterior prerenal space as well as in the anterior, posterior, and lateroconal fascia. There were no signs of chronic pancreatitis or vascular complications, but you did have two similar episodes of acute tail pancreatitis in the following months. Patient: Oh, I see. Doctor: In September 2009, you presented with vague epigastric pain lasting several weeks. Your serum amylase and lipase levels were normal, but your cholestatic parameters were mildly elevated. We performed a magnetic resonance (MR) study, which demonstrated moderate chronic pancreatitis of the tail with atrophy and irregular bordering of the Wirsung's duct. No other abnormalities were found, but further examinations revealed a Helicobacter pylori gastritis. Patient: Hmm, that's concerning. Doctor: In February 2012, you presented again to the gastroenterologist with epigastric and left upper quadrant pain. Your laboratory findings were not suspect for acute pancreatitis. However, we performed a contrast-enhanced CT scan to evaluate the known chronic pancreatitis and other potential causes of your pain. Patient: And what did the scan find? Doctor: The CT scan revealed a hypervascular lesion in the pancreatic tail, consisting of a conglomeration of small hypervascular spots and blood vessels. summarization: Subjective: The patient, with a history of alcohol abuse, presents with severe epigastric pain and nausea persisting for two days. He has a past medical history of similar episodes and has been previously diagnosed with chronic pancreatitis and Helicobacter pylori gastritis. Objective: Current laboratory tests raised suspicions of pancreatitis. A CT scan revealed an edematous pancreas tail and fluid in the anterior prerenal space and surrounding fascia, with no signs of chronic changes or vascular complications. Previous imaging and tests in 2009 and 2012 showed chronic pancreatitis and a pancreatic arteriovenous malformation, respectively. Assessment: The primary diagnosis is acute pancreatitis, likely related to the patient's history of alcohol abuse and chronic pancreatic conditions. Differential diagnoses previously considered include vascular malformations and hypervascular pancreatic tumors, which were ruled out through further imaging and angiography, confirming a pancreatic arteriovenous malformation. document: Doctor: Good morning, I'm Dr. Smith. I heard you were brought to the emergency department by ambulance yesterday due to altered mental status. Can you tell me what happened? Patient: Hi, Dr. Smith. My mother found me in my apartment yesterday feeling very confused and lethargic. She called emergency services because she was worried about me. Doctor: I see. According to your mother, you mentioned taking a large amount of ibuprofen in a suicide attempt earlier that day. Is that correct? Patient: Yes, I took around 300 tablets of 200 mg ibuprofen, so it must have been around 60,000 mg in total. Doctor: That's a very high dose. Do you have any known allergies to medications? Patient: No, I don't have any allergies to medications. Doctor: I understand you have a medical history of depression, asthma, alcohol abuse, and prior drug abuse, including cocaine, Percocet, and intravenous heroin. Is that correct? Patient: Yes, that's correct. I completed a drug rehabilitation program six months ago and haven't been using illegal drugs since then. I still smoke half a pack of cigarettes a day and occasionally drink alcohol with friends. Doctor: It's good to hear you've been staying away from illegal drugs. I also see that you have a surgical history of breast reduction surgery. Now, let's talk about your family's medical history. Your father has hypertension, your mother has non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, and your aunt has cryptogenic cirrhosis, right? Patient: Yes, that's correct. Doctor: When you were brought in, your vital signs were temperature 98 degrees Fahrenheit, pulse 111 beats per minute, blood pressure 109/66 mmHg, respiratory rate 17, and oxygen saturation 97% on room air. Your physical exam showed lethargy, but nothing else significant. Your initial complete blood count (CBC) and basic metabolic panel (BMP) were within normal limits. Patient: Okay, so what happened after that? Doctor: To protect your airway, you were intubated and admitted to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for further treatment. Due to the ibuprofen overdose, you were emergently hemodialyzed overnight. Patient: So, what's the

His family history includes hypertension, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease and cryptogenic cirrhosis. Physical examination showed lethargy, but nothing else significant. Initial complete blood count (CBC) and basic metabolic panel (BMP) were within normal limits. CBC showed 98 degrees Fahrenheit, pulse 111 beats per minute, blood pressure 109 /66 mmHg, respiratory rate 17, and oxygen saturation 97% on room air. The physical examination revealed lethal pulmonary thrombosis, despite ibuprofen overdose, which occurred overnight. Medical history is based on the patient's family has been relapsed, as well as previous drug abuse and prior drug use, including cocaine and alcohol. She has not been using illegal drugs since then.
summarization: Subjective: The patient, a known case of depression, asthma, alcohol, and prior drug abuse, was found by his mother feeling confused and lethargic. He admitted to ingesting approximately 60,000 mg of ibuprofen in a suicide attempt. He denies any medication allergies and reports abstinence from illegal drugs for six months, though he continues to smoke and occasionally consumes alcohol. Objective: Upon admission, the patient's vital signs were: temperature 98°F, pulse 111 bpm, blood pressure 109/66 mmHg, respiratory rate 17, and oxygen saturation 97% on room air. Physical examination revealed lethargy but was otherwise unremarkable. Initial CBC and BMP were within normal limits. The patient was intubated and underwent emergency hemodialysis due to the ibuprofen overdose. Assessment: The primary diagnosis is acute ibuprofen overdose, complicated by altered mental status requiring intubation and hemodialysis. Differential diagnoses include complications from chronic substance abuse and underlying psychiatric conditions like depression. The prognosis depends on the patient

There is end-stage AMD in your left eye and subretinal hemorrhage in your right eye. I think we should refer you for an ocular ultrasound. We will initiate Anti-VEGF treatment and continue it for several months. However, an MRI of the orbits with contrast showed a subcentimeter region of abnormal contrast enhancement extending into the adjacent retro-bulbar fat, which is suspicious for scleral invasion and small extrascleral lesional extension (Fig.). document: Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today? Patient: Hi, I am a 26-year-old primigravida and I am 23 weeks pregnant. I have a distension in my abdomen that's worrying me. Doctor: I see. Can you tell me about your past medical history? Patient: Yes, two years ago, I had a left salpingo-oopherectomy for an ovarian mucinous adenocarcinoma. I received six cycles of combined chemotherapy with carboplatin and paclitaxel afterward and was advised to use contraception. I didn't follow up after that, and now I am pregnant. Doctor: Thank you for providing that information. Let's do an abdomen examination to check for any issues. *After examining the patient* It appears that there is some ascites and your uterus is about the size of a 24 weeks pregnancy with palpable fetal parts. We should also do an ultrasound examination to investigate further. Patient: Okay, what did you find in the ultrasound? Doctor: The ultrasound shows an intra-uterine pregnancy of 23 weeks and a right ovarian mass of 12.8 x 8.8 cm with solid and cystic areas containing free fluid with internal echoes. Your CA-125 level is also elevated at 80 IU/ml. Based on these findings, it seems like you have recurrent ovarian cancer during your pregnancy. Patient: Oh no, what are my options? Doctor: Ideally, we would recommend surgical management to address the cancer. However, I understand that you declined this option. Instead, we started you on two courses of chemotherapy with a single dose of carboplatin 450mg intravenously at three-week intervals. Patient: Yes, I remember that. But I couldn't do the third course because my liver function tests were not good. Doctor: That's correct. Unfortunately, the ascites has been progressive, which has led to maternal respiratory distress and fetal growth restriction and oligohydroamnios. We have decided to plan an elective Cesarean section with staging laparotomy at 34 weeks for the breech presentation with decreased liquor and gross ascites, after completion of steroid cover. Patient: What will happen during the surgery? Doctor: Intraoperatively

summarization: Subjective: The patient is a 26-year-old primigravida at 23 weeks gestation, presenting with abdominal distension. She has a history of left salpingo-oophorectomy for ovarian mucinous adenocarcinoma and subsequent chemotherapy. She reports non-compliance with contraceptive advice post-treatment and no follow-up until the current pregnancy. She expresses concerns about her current health and the health of her fetus. document: Doctor: Hello, I'm reviewing your case and it looks like you're a 52-year-old gentleman, asymptomatic and a nonsmoker, without any comorbidities but with class II obesity, as your BMI is 37.7. Is that correct? Patient: Yes, that's right. Doctor: You were referred to us from the lung cancer screening program. The high-resolution chest computed tomography (CT) scan showed a 1.5 cm mixed ground glass opacity (GGO) with a larger solid component in your right middle lobe (RML). Have you experienced any symptoms related to this? Patient: No, I haven't felt anything unusual. Doctor: Okay. The nodule increased in size at the follow-up CT scan, so we decided to resect the middle lobe anatomically using subcostal access. You were given general anesthesia with double lumen endotracheal intubation and placed in a lateral decubitus position, at dorsal decubitus 40 degrees. Does that sound familiar? Patient: Yes, I remember that part. Doctor: We made a 5 cm oblique incision parallel to the costal arch, and then the subcutaneous tissue and rectus abdominis were dissected along the subcostal margin. We detached the xiphoid process and pericardiophrenic fatty tissue. A subcostal tunnel was bluntly dissected using a finger until the mediastinal pleura was opened at the cardiophrenic angle. We then placed a covidien wound protector (WPLGR914). Patient: Hmm, okay. Doctor: We used a thoracoscopic lens with a 30° angle (Olympus, Melville, NY) to examine the interlobar fissure. Lobectomy was performed as shown in the video [subcostal right middle lobe lobectomy video]. We also carried out a systematic mediastinal lymph nodes dissection, which included stations 2, 4 right paratracheal, 9, 10, 11, 12, and subcarinal lymph nodes. We used long and sturdier VATS instruments, as well as curved tip stapler technology that aids

Differential diagnoses could include benign etiologies like infectious or inflammatory processes, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical context. document: Doctor: Hello, I see that you've presented to the Department of Neurosurgery today. What brings you in? Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been having this left facial droop and some spasms on the same side. Doctor: I see. Other than the facial droop and spasm, do you have any relevant past medical or surgical history? Patient: No, I don't have any other medical or surgical history. Doctor: Alright. Based on your symptoms and our examination, it appears you have an unruptured right middle cerebral artery (MCA) aneurysm. We will need to admit you to the hospital for a right-sided craniotomy to clip the aneurysm. Patient: Oh, okay. What does that procedure involve? Doctor: The procedure is called a pterional craniotomy, and it will be performed under general anesthesia. During the surgery, we will use intraoperative neurophysiological monitoring methods to ensure your safety. Patient: What does that monitoring involve? Doctor: We will use median, ulnar, and posterior tibial nerve somatosensory evoked potentials (SSEP) in a standard fashion. These methods help us monitor the function of your motor pathways during the surgery. Transcranial motor evoked potential (TCMEP) and direct cortical motor evoked potential (DCMEP) will also be used. Patient: I see. And what about the stimulation? Doctor: For TCMEP, we will use a multi-pulse train of six with a pulse width of 50 sec and an interstimulus interval (ISI) of 2 ms (500 Hz). The voltage stimulation will be between 100 and 300 volts, controlling for the inhibition of the "crossover" response. For DCMEP, the stimulation parameters include a multi-pulse train of five delivered at a constant current of 15 mA with a pulse width of 500 sec and an ISI of 2 ms (500 Hz). Patient: Okay, that's a lot of information. What about the monitoring sites? Doctor: We will use upper and lower extremity muscles as target acquisition sites. The patient is scheduled for a right-sided pterional craniotomy under general anesthesia with intraoperative neurophysiological monitoring, including median, ulnar, and posterior tibial nerve somatosensory evoked potentials (SSEP), transcranial motor evoked potential (TCMEP), and direct cortical motor evoked potential (DCMEP). Monitoring parameters for TCMEP include a multi-pulse train of six with a pulse width of 50 sec and an interstimulus interval (ISI) of 2 ms (500 Hz), voltage stimulation between 100 and 300 volts. For DCMEP, parameters include a multi-pulse train of five delivered at a constant current of 15 mA with a pulse width of 500 sec and an ISI of 2 ms (500 Hz).

document: Doctor: Hello, I see that you presented to the Emergency Department in December 2020 with a large ulcerated and necrotic bulging lesion on your forehead. Can you tell me more about how it started and how it has progressed? Patient: Yes, it started as a small 2 cm bruise-like patch on my forehead about four months before I came to the hospital. document: Doctor: Hello, I see that you're a 31-year-old female patient with symptomatic postpartum deep venous thrombosis in your right leg. Can you describe the symptoms you've been experiencing? Patient: Yeah, my right leg has been really swollen and painful. It's been difficult to walk around. Doctor: I understand. So, before your surgical thrombectomy, you received a suprarenal IVC filter due to the short distance between the thrombus in the distal IVC and the inflow of renal veins. The surgical access was established via venotomy of the common femoral vein, and an occlusion balloon was used for the thrombectomy. How did you feel after the procedure? Patient: I felt a bit better, but still had some pain and swelling in my leg. Doctor: Hmm, I see. In a follow-up CT, we found that the filter had dislodged and tilted towards the right IVC wall with its legs piercing the contralateral wall and extending into the left renal vein. This was likely due to the surgical thrombectomy. You were given oral anticoagulation with Warfarin, but unfortunately, there was a re-thrombosis. We then performed catheter-directed thrombolysis, including stenting of the common iliac veins and the IVC. However, we didn't attempt filter retrieval at that time due to the large amount of clot within the filter. Patient: Oh, I see. So, what happened next? Doctor: After 5 weeks of Warfarin therapy, you were scheduled for a retrieval, which was considered mandatory due to the displaced and tilted filter with penetrating legs. We introduced a 14-F sheath, an SOS catheter, a Bentson wire, and an EN Snare to create a loop. We attempted the single loop-snare technique several times, but it kept slipping around the filter legs. Patient: That sounds difficult. What did you do then? Doctor: To stabilize the loop, we formed a second loop using the same technique around the filter tip. With two loops around the filter tip, we were finally able to successfully pull the filter away

document: Doctor: Hello, young lady. How can I help you today? Patient: Hi, doctor. I've been having this problem with my neck swelling up on the left side since I was 6 years old. Doctor: I see. Have you had any treatment for this swelling? Patient: Yes, I had some treatment to control the inflammation. Doctor: Good. Did you have any tests done after the inflammation was controlled? Patient: Yes, I had a barium esophagography done. Doctor: Alright. And what did the results show? Patient: The results showed a PSF on the left side of my neck. Doctor: Okay, and did you have a CT scan as well? Patient: Yes, and it showed an air- and barium-containing fistula. Doctor: I understand. We decided to perform a MLS as the first-line treatment for you. Do you remember the details of the procedure? Patient: Hmm, I remember the doctor saying that the fistula was narrow and the tissue wasn't fragile. Doctor: That's correct. We made the incision as small as possible during the surgery (Fig., ). The operation was completed uneventfully (Fig. ). On the fifth postoperative day, we performed another barium esophagography. Did you experience any leakage after that? Patient: No, there wasn't any leakage. Doctor: Great. You were able to start free oral intake on the same day, right? Patient: Yes, I was able to eat and drink without any problems. Doctor: I'm glad to hear that. You had an uneventful recovery and were discharged from the hospital 7 days after the surgery. How have you been feeling since then? Patient: I've been feeling much better, and I haven't had any recurrence of the swelling. Doctor: That's excellent news. I'm happy to hear that you're doing well. Remember to come back for regular check-ups to ensure everything remains fine. If you ever experience any issues, don't hesitate to contact us. Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help and guidance.
prediction: Subjective: The patient has a neck swelling up on the left side since she was 6 years old. She has had some treatment to control the inflammation, including barium esophagography, MLS, and CT scans. The results showed an air- containing fistula, but no leakage after the surgery. On the fifth postoperative day, the patient was discharged from the hospital 7 days after surgery with uneventful recovery and free oral intake. Despite recurrence of the swelling, she hasn't had any leakages, although she's feeling much better. After surgery, they performed another Barium Esophageography as the first-line treatment for the neck, which included an Air-and-barium-containing Fisula.
summarization: Subjective: The patient, a young female, reports a history of left-sided neck swelling since age 6. She mentions previous treatments aimed at controlling inflammation and has undergone diagnostic evaluations including barium esophagography and CT scan, which identified a PSF (pharyngeal salivary fistula) containing air and barium. Objective: The patient underwent a minimally invasive lateral surgery (MLS) to address the fistula, described as narrow with non-fragile tissue. Postoperative evaluations showed no leakage, and she was able to resume oral intake immediately after the procedure. She was discharged 7 days post-surgery without complications. Assessment: The primary diagnosis is a left-sided pharyngeal salivary fistula. The successful surgical intervention and absence of postoperative complications or recurrence of symptoms suggest a positive outcome. Plan: The patient is advised to continue regular follow-ups to monitor for any potential recurrence or complications. She is encouraged to report any new symptoms immediately. No additional treatment is currently required given the successful postoperative recovery and lack of symptoms.

document: Doctor: Hello, I understand that you are here for an evaluation of your ascites and treatment of AN-BP. Can you please tell me about your history with self-induced vomiting and laxative abuse? Patient: Yes, I've been dealing with self-induced vomiting and laxative abuse for 20 years now. I've been taking more than 200 tablets per day. Doctor: That's quite severe. Have you received any previous treatments for this issue? Patient: Yes, I've had supportive psychotherapy and symptomatic treatment from psychiatrists, including being hospitalized 13 times. Doctor: I see. During the physical examination, we noticed some epigastric vein dilatation and striae cutis distensae on your swelling abdomen, which was filled with ascites. We also conducted some blood tests. The results indicated hypoalbuminemia, increased hepatic and biliary enzyme levels, an increased creatinine level, hypokalemia, and anemia. Have you experienced any symptoms related to these findings? Patient: Yeah, I've been feeling really tired and weak lately. Doctor: That could be due to the anemia. We also performed an abdominal ultrasonogram, which showed findings of chronic hepatitis, such as an irregular liver surface, a dull margin, and heterogeneity of the parenchyma. A computed tomography scan revealed a gastro-renal shunt, but no varices were detected. We suspected portal hypertension due to liver cirrhosis, so we performed a liver biopsy. Patient: What did the liver biopsy show? Doctor: The biopsy showed only slight pericellular fibrosis without evidence of liver cirrhosis. However, liver fibrosis was proven by the increase in liver fibrosis markers, such as type IV collagen 7S (8.5 ng/mL) and hyaluronic acid (400 ng/mL). We also conducted psychological testing, which showed remarkable depression and anxiety. Patient: What's the plan for my treatment? Doctor: During your inpatient care, we provided nutritional treatment and diuretic drugs to control the ascites. After your general state improved, we initiated an inpatient cognitive behavioral treatment. You were discharged 2 months after admission because your ascites almost disappeared and your body weight increased by

He has received supportive psychotherapy and symptomatic treatment, including hospitalization 13 times. Blood tests indicated hypoalbuminemia, increased biliary enzyme levels, an increased creatinine level, hypokalemia and anemia. Clinical examination showed irregular liver surface, dull margin, and heterogeneity of the parenchyma. A computed tomography scan revealed gastro-renal shunt, suggesting portal hypertension due to liver cirrhosis. The biopsy showed slight pericellular fibrosis without evidence of liver
summarization: Subjective: The patient, with a 20-year history of self-induced vomiting and laxative abuse, reports feeling tired and weak. The patient has been hospitalized 13 times and has undergone supportive psychotherapy and symptomatic treatment. The chief complaints are ascites and symptoms of anorexia nervosa-binge/purge type (AN-BP). Objective: Physical examination revealed epigastric vein dilatation and striae cutis distensae. Blood tests showed hypoalbuminemia, elevated hepatic and biliary enzyme levels, increased creatinine, hypokalemia, and anemia. Abdominal ultrasonogram indicated chronic hepatitis, and CT scan showed a gastro-renal shunt without varices. Liver biopsy indicated slight pericellular fibrosis, and psychological testing revealed significant depression and anxiety. Despite treatment, serum levels of AST, ALT, ALP, -GTP, and creatinine have not improved significantly. Assessment: The primary diagnosis is chronic hepatitis with complications of portal hypertension and ascites, secondary to long-term AN

document: Doctor: Hello, I see that you're a 55-year-old African American male with a significant past medical history of breast cancer. What brings you in today? Patient: I recently had a surveillance computed tomography (CT) scan of my chest, abdomen, and pelvis, and they found something. Doctor: Yes, I see here that the CT scan showed incidental acute appendicitis. Were you experiencing any symptoms when you came in for the scan? Patient: No, I was asymptomatic during the scan, but in the following days, I developed nausea and vomiting along with right lower quadrant abdominal pain. Doctor: That's consistent with appendicitis. We'll have to admit you to the general surgery service for treatment. I also noticed from your chart that you have an extensive history with cancer, is that correct? Patient: Yeah, it all started in 2014 when I had a resection of an enlarging, ulcerating chest mass on the right side. Doctor: I see that the pathology report from the wide local excision of the mass demonstrated estrogen receptor-positive, progesterone receptor-positive, and HER2/neu-negative metastatic adenocarcinoma. At the time, the primary source of the cancer was unknown. You underwent esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) and colonoscopy, both of which were normal, correct? Patient: Yes, that's right. My oncology team has been closely monitoring me, and I've been treated with tamoxifen for hormone therapy. Doctor: I also noticed that in May of 2017, due to an enlarged anterior mediastinal wall lymph node discovered on CT surveillance, you underwent a CT-guided biopsy and positron emission tomography (PET). The biopsy was negative for malignancy, but the PET showed abnormal hypermetabolic activity within a retrosternal nodule, intense activity in a mixed focus in the manubrium, and several hypermetabolic nodes within the mediastinum. It also showed an abnormal hypermetabolic focus in the cecum, which was suspicious for a colon primary. Is that correct? Patient: Yes, they tried to do a colonoscopy, but the gastroenterologist couldn't

summarization: Subjective: The patient is a 55-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for breast cancer, presenting with recent nausea, vomiting, and right lower quadrant abdominal pain. He was asymptomatic at the time of a surveillance CT scan, which later revealed acute appendicitis. He has a history of estrogen receptor-positive, progesterone receptor-positive, and HER2/neu-negative metastatic adenocarcinoma, initially presenting as an enlarging, ulcerating chest mass on the right side in 2014. He has been under close oncological surveillance and treated with tamoxifen. Objective: Recent CT scan showed incidental acute appendicitis. Past imaging and biopsies have shown various sites of hypermetabolic activity and metastatic adenocarcinoma consistent with his known breast cancer. Vital signs and further specifics on current physical examination findings are not provided in the transcript. Assessment: Primary diagnosis is acute appendicitis, with a significant background of metastatic breast cancer. Differential diagnosis for his systemic symptoms may include complications or progression of his known cancer;

Doctor: I understand. I see from your medical history that you had aortic valve stenosis and received an orthotopic heart transplantation in 1994 for idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy. I've been mostly asymptomatic except for paroxysmal atrial flutter. I got a single chamber pacemaker in 2008 and then had an atrial flutter ablation in 2010. Doctor: That's good to hear. Have you been adhering to your medication regimen? Patient: Yep, I've been taking my meds as prescribed. Doctor: Great. However, you do have some post-transplant cardiovascular risk factors like systemic hypertension, dyslipidaemia, and stable stage 4 chronic renal dysfunction with an eGFR of 23 mL/min/1.73 m2. We've been monitoring your condition with serial transthoracic echocardiography at our institution, and it has shown progressive degenerative aortic valve disease. document: Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today? Patient: Hi, doctor. I am a 75-year-old woman, and I've been having a loss of appetite for a week now. I'm 132 cm tall and weigh 34 kg. Doctor: I see. Are you taking any medications currently? Patient: Yes, I take aspirin, celecoxib, and amlodipine for angina and hypertension. Doctor: Alright. I will need to run some laboratory examinations to better understand your condition. *After the examinations* Doctor: Your lab results show that your Hb has decreased modestly to 10.7 g/dl. I would like to monitor your condition and ask that you return in two weeks for a follow-up. Patient: Okay, thank you. *Two weeks later* Patient: Doctor, my anorexia has worsened day by day, and I decided to admit myself to the hospital. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. On admission day 1, you were alert and fully oriented. Your blood pressure and pulse rate were stable. However, your laboratory examinations showed that your Hb and hematocrit levels decreased remarkably to 4.8 g/dl and 15%, respectively. Your white blood count and C-reactive protein (CRP) increased slightly to 9900 /mm3 and 4.64 mg/dl, respectively. Additionally, your albumin level decreased to 2.5 g/dl and your creatine level increased slightly to 1.14 mg/dl, with an estimated glomerular filtration rate of 41.7 ml/min. We also conducted chest and abdominal computed tomography (CT), but it didn't detect any abnormal lesions. Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good. Doctor: On admission day 2, you vomited large amounts of bright red blood, and your Hb level further decreased to 2.9 g/dl. We performed an urgent transfusion of 560 ml of red blood cells. An endoscopic examination detected active bleeding from a gastric ulcer, so we performed endoscopic clipping on the bleeding lesion. Patient: I'm glad you found the issue. Did my Hb levels improve after that? Doctor: Yes, your Hb improved to 8.9 g/dl. However, you did not respond

document: Doctor: Hello, can you tell me why you were admitted to the hospital back in June 2016? Patient: Yeah, I was admitted because of weakness in my right arm and problems with my speech, like slurring. Doctor: I see. You were diagnosed with cerebral infarction in the left middle cerebral artery area and deep vein thrombosis. Your ECG demonstrated normal sinus rhythm and echocardiography revealed no intra-cardiac thrombus or vegetation. You were then discharged with a prescription for apixaban. Is that correct? Patient: Yes, that's right. Doctor: In August 2016, you were readmitted to the hospital due to recurrent right arm weakness and slurred speech. The MRI showed multiple cerebral infarctions in both cerebral hemispheres and the cerebellum. At this point, Trousseau's syndrome was suspected. Do you remember that? Patient: Yes, I do. Doctor: So, your apixaban was stopped and you were given an intravenous drip of heparin instead. Echocardiography revealed mild mitral regurgitation with vegetation on the mitral valve. Although your lab results showed no evidence of infection, you were given ceftriaxone and gentamicin as a precaution against infective endocarditis. You were then referred to our hospital for surgery. Patient: Yes, I remember that. Doctor: A CT scan revealed a left renal infarction and multiple swollen lymph nodes around both the abdominal aorta and stomach with antral hypertrophy. This suggested advanced gastric cancer or lymphoma. Despite the heparin and antibiotics therapy, the vegetation on your mitral valve didn't change. So, cardiac surgery was performed on day 5 after your referral. Patient: Okay, and what happened during the surgery? Doctor: During the surgery, extracorporeal circulation was instituted employing aortic and bicaval cannulation. After aortic cross-clamping, the mitral valve was exposed via a left atriotomy. Both mitral leaflets had vegetation on the surface, and a major vegetation 15 mm in width was evident on the anterior leaflet. These were resected in their entirety and replaced with a

document: Doctor: Hi there, I heard you've been experiencing some wrist pain and unsightly appearance of your wrist after a previous fracture. Can you please describe how it feels and when these symptoms started to develop? Patient: Yeah, the pain is mostly on the ulnar side of my wrist, and it started about a year after the fracture. The appearance of my wrist seems a bit deformed too. Doctor: I see. Based on the physical examination and the tests we ran, it appears that you have a growth plate fracture in your right distal radius, specifically a SalterHarris type II fracture. You were initially treated with cast immobilization and closed reduction, which allowed the fracture to heal. However, the wrist pain and deformity you're experiencing now are due to a condition called partial physeal arrest. Patient: Oh, I see. What does that mean? Doctor: Partial physeal arrest occurs when the growth plate in your wrist is damaged, causing it to stop growing properly. In your case, radiographs showed a shortening deformity of the distal radius and an abnormal radial inclination of the articular surface. A CT scan was also performed to evaluate the deformity and for preoperative simulation with a low-radiation setting. Patient: So, what's the plan to fix this? Doctor: We have planned a two-stage operation for you. The first stage will involve a procedure called distraction osteogenesis to gradually lengthen the affected bone. The second stage will be the Langenskiöld procedure, which aims to remove the physeal bar and reestablish physeal growth. Patient: Will this help with the pain and appearance of my wrist? Doctor: Yes, the goal of the operation is to correct the deformities of the wrist and improve its appearance and function. In the first operation, we'll use a closed-wedge osteotomy to correct the distal radius, and an external fixator called the Orthofix MiniRail FixatorTM will be used for lengthening. Patient: Okay, that sounds good. What do I need to do to prepare for the surgery? Doctor: We have obtained informed consent from your guardians to report the procedure and proceed with the operation. All procedures have been approved by the Ethics Committee of

document: Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today? Patient: Hi, I've been experiencing some issues lately. I work at a shrimp farm in Yingkou, and I had watery diarrhea on August 24th. Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about your symptoms and any relevant history? Patient: Well, I had a single episode of watery diarrhea, dizziness, and vomiting after consuming raw mollusc from the sediment in Yingkou. I don't have any immune-compromising diseases, and I don't abuse alcohol. Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. How did you manage your symptoms after the episode? Patient: I took ciprofloxacin for two days, and the watery diarrhea disappeared after three days of antibiotic treatment. Doctor: Okay, it seems that the antibiotic helped. Did you have any laboratory tests done? Patient: Yes, I had some biochemical tests and my white blood cell count was high, 14  109/L. They also did a stool culture. Doctor: Were there any findings from the stool culture? Patient: The stool culture was spread onto Thiosulfate-citrate-bile salts-sucrose and MacConkey agar plates, and it showed suspected positive results for V. cholerae. Doctor: I see. Were there any further tests done to confirm the presence of V. cholerae? Patient: Yes, they obtained a pure culture and identified the bacterium as V. cholerae through the VITEK-2 bacterial identifier system and sequencing of the 16S rDNA genes. Doctor: Did they perform any tests to determine the specific strain of V. cholerae? Patient: They did an agglutination test with O1 and O139 antisera, and it showed that the strain was a non-O1/O139 V. cholerae. Doctor: Alright. Were there any tests conducted to assess the virulence factors of the V. cholerae strain? Patient: Yes, they did a PCR test for outer membrane protein, TCP expression, haemagglutinin, protease, and central regulatory protein, among others. Doctor: What were the results of the PCR tests? document: Doctor: Good morning, how can I help you today? Patient: Hi, Doctor. I was diagnosed with left temporal glial neoplasia in May 2014 after I had a seizure. Doctor: I see. document: Doctor: Hello, can you please tell me about the injuries you sustained? Patient: Hi, I had an electrical burn from a power line. It was pretty bad. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. It looks like you had 32% total body surface area third-degree injuries. Can you tell me more about the injury to your left knee? Patient: Yeah, my left knee got an open joint injury. It was treated with three skin grafting procedures before something else was placed. Doctor: That's right. The SEF, or spatial external fixator, was placed 24 days after your injury to help stabilize your knee. It was kept on for 8.5 weeks. We used Shantz pins and bars as the external fixator, and it was locked in full extension. Patient: Oh, I see. So, what happened after the SEF was placed? Doctor: After the SEF placement, you required two additional skin grafting procedures on your left knee. You also had a bony prominence resection while in SEF. This means we removed a protruding piece of bone to help with your recovery. Patient: I didn't know that. Were there any complications during my treatment? Doctor: No significant complications were recorded during your treatment, which is good news. However, I noticed that there were no PT/OT notes or follow-up recorded. Patient: Hmm, what does that mean? Doctor: PT/OT refers to physical therapy and occupational therapy. It's important to have these sessions and follow-ups to ensure proper recovery and regain function in your injured knee. Patient: Oh, okay. So, what should I do now? Doctor: I would recommend scheduling an appointment with a physical therapist and an occupational therapist to assess your current condition and create a plan for your ongoing recovery. Patient: Alright, I'll do that. Thanks for explaining everything to me. Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any further questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out. Take care and wishing you a speedy recovery.
