document: Doctor: Hi, I understand you recently presented to an outside institution with an acute episode of aphasia. Can you tell me more about that? Patient: Yeah, it was quite sudden. I had difficulty speaking and understanding what others were saying. Doctor: I see. The MR-imaging that was performed revealed an enhancing left temporal mass, with a maximum enhancing diameter of 2.1 cm (Fig.). The biopsy of the lesion showed that it was histologically consistent with GBM. The test results were IDH1R132H negative, 1p/19q intact, MGMT unmethylated, p53 positive, and without EGFR amplification. Patient: Hmm, okay. Doctor: To treat this, you underwent LITT, which involved an energy of 24.42 kJ, 876 pulses, and a time of 0:29:07. The treatment was done using a single track approximately 4 cm in length. You were discharged home on post-treatment day 2 at your neurological baseline. Is that correct? Patient: Yes, that's right. Doctor: About two weeks after LITT, you came to our institution with complaints of increasing headache and calculation difficulties, despite being on corticosteroid therapy. Do you remember that? Patient: Yes, the headaches were getting worse, and I had trouble doing simple math. Doctor: I understand. The MR-imaging we did revealed tissue necrosis with hemorrhagic material within the LITT treated region and edema surrounding the treatment site. To address this, you underwent en bloc resection of the enhancing lesion and adjacent tumor-infiltrated brain via a left temporal craniotomy (Fig.). Your headache and calculation difficulties resolved after the surgery and you were discharged on post-operative day 2. Patient: Yes, I felt much better after the surgery. Doctor: That's great to hear. Post-operative MR-imaging confirmed complete resection of the enhancing lesion. You also underwent adjuvant radiation therapy and were treated to a dose of 5945 cGy in 29 fractions with concurrent temozolomide. However, the maintenance temozolomide was discontinued after 5 cycles due to persistent pancytopenia. Patient: Yeah, I remember that.

document: Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today? Patient: I presented to the emergency room with sudden right lower quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting. Doctor: I see. Let me perform a physical exam to check for any signs of appendicitis. Have you experienced any similar symptoms in the past? Patient: Yes, five years ago I had diffuse abdominal pain and a CT scan identified a lesion in my small bowel. The endoscopic biopsy showed it was GIST. Doctor: Did you undergo any treatment for that? Patient: I had a resection without complications. No pathology was available, and according to me, no adjuvant chemotherapy was given. I was symptom-free for the next several years. Doctor: Thank you for the information. I'll need to perform some tests to check for any signs of recurrence. In the meantime, I'll also check your white blood cell count. Patient: Okay, thank you. document: Doctor: Hello, I see that you're an 11-year-old female who presented to the emergency department and was admitted to the hospital in October 2016 with a 1-month history of extreme right lower extremity burning pain and seizure-like activity. Can you describe your symptoms and how frequently they occur? Patient: Yeah, my right leg has been hurting really badly, and I have these seizure-like episodes. We also performed an EEG because of the frequent seizure-like activity, but it was negative, so the diagnosis is pseudoseizures. Patient: No, they haven't really helped with the pain or the seizures. Doctor: I see. We also evaluated psychogenic causes and looked into your children's hospital records. Doctor: After about 10 sessions, we should see some improvement in your pain and a decrease in pseudoseizures from 25 to 30 per day to 12-15 per day, lasting half the previous average time of 2-3 minutes. document: Doctor: Hello, I understand that you are a 48-year-old employed male, and you have been diagnosed with bipolar 1 disorder. You were recently admitted to our inpatient psychiatric unit for the treatment of severe bipolar 1 depression. Is that correct? Patient: Yes, that's correct. About two months ago, I was involuntarily hospitalized at another facility for mania. Doctor: I see. Before your admission, we obtained standard laboratory measures, which were within normal limits, and a urine toxicology screen, which was negative. Can you tell me about your symptoms during the initial days on our service? Patient: Sure. I was feeling really depressed and had low energy. I slept through the night and most of the day. I rarely attended group therapy or socialized with the staff or other patients. Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. We started you on modafinil 100 mg daily with plans to use it short term to help combat your hypersomnia. At that time, your psychiatric medications included divalproex 2,500 mg QHS, quetiapine 300 mg QHS, and venlafaxine 225 mg once daily. Venlafaxine had been increased to 225 mg several weeks prior to the initiation of modafinil. Your valproic acid level was 79 ug/ml, confirming adequate prophylactic treatment of mania. There were no other changes made to your medication regimen at this time. Did you notice any changes in your symptoms after we started the modafinil? Patient: Yeah, two days after starting modafinil, I began to have some weird symptoms, like seeing trees moving in my bedroom and thinking there were cameras in the pictures on my wall. I also thought a water bottle was transmitting something into my room. Doctor: I see. And did you experience any other psychotic behaviors during that time? Patient: Yes, I woke up my roommate in the middle of the night, accusing him of abusing his daughter, and later, I accused the treatment team of including me in experimental research. Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. Following these psychotic events, we decided to discontinue the modafinil, and your psychotic features subsided within the following days. How are you feeling now? Patient: I'm feeling much better now, thank you.

Then, we'll exchange the SMC for a 4-French Berenstein catheter and place an 8.5-French nephro-ureterostomy stent from Cook Medical. Patient: And where will the stent be placed? Patient: Yes, I've had a history of black stools and anemia for about 3 years now. My past medical history includes multiple comorbidities like diabetes, chronic renal failure, alcoholic cirrhosis Child A, complete heart blockade, and thrombocytopenia of unknown etiology. Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. We performed an upper endoscopy and biopsy which revealed a well-differentiated intestinal type adenocarcinoma in the antrum. Endoscopic ultrasonography showed a hypoechoic, 3.2 cm neoplasm, without muscularis externa infiltration and reactive ganglia. Patient: Hmm, what does that mean? Doctor: It means that we have identified a tumor in your stomach. Given the tumor size, stage, and your comorbidities, we chose endoscopic mucosal resection as the best treatment option. The tumor was fully resected without complications. Patient: That's a relief. So, what happened after the procedure? Doctor: During the procedure, the anesthesiologist had difficulty with ventilation and abdominal distention was observed. Your blood pressure was 128/91 mmHg and your heart rate was 70 bpm. We performed an endoscopic revision before finishing the procedure, but we didn't identify any macroscopic perforation. Patient: So, what did you do next? Doctor: We placed a nasogastric tube and instituted therapeutic strategies to improve abdominal-wall compliance, such as changes in ventilation parameters, nasogastric suction, changing your position to supine, and removal of any strap over the abdomen. A plain abdominal radiography in the operating room showed a massive pneumoperitoneum. Patient: What did you decide to do after that? Doctor: We decided on a nonsurgical management approach and took you to the intensive care unit (ICU) for monitoring. The intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) measured by a trans-bladder catheter was 33 mmHg. Patient: What happened in the ICU? Doctor

document: Doctor: Hello, I have reviewed your case as the second patient. It seems that you have a history of hypertension and delirium. How has your blood pressure been lately? Patient: Oh, it's been well controlled recently. Doctor: That's good to hear. I also noticed that you're taking dementia medicine. Are you able to follow commands well? Patient: Yes, I can follow commands without any problem. Doctor: Great. We conducted a pulmonary function test, and the results indicated an obstructive pattern. Are you aware of this? Patient: Yes, I remember being told about that. Doctor: Alright. We performed a total hip arthroplasty using the same anesthetic regimen used for the first patient. During the surgery, while ventilating at an FiO2 of 0.4, you experienced hypoxia. Your O2 saturation level dropped from 100% to 80%, and your PaO2 dropped from 129 to 53.0. Do you remember any shortness of breath or discomfort during this time? Patient: Hmm, I don't recall any specific feeling, but it was a bit uncomfortable at times. Doctor: I see. We administered a muscle relaxant-reversing agent which helped you recover spontaneous respiration. Your O2 saturation level improved from 81% to 88%. We then applied continuous positive airway pressure, and your O2 saturation level further improved to 90%. After the surgery, your O2 saturation level increased to 98%. How are you feeling now? Patient: I feel much better now, thank you. Doctor: That's good to know. I want to inform you that neither you nor the first patient developed any respiratory complications after the surgery. The postoperative chest X-ray showed no notable findings for the first patient. However, in your case, it showed subsegmental atelectasis on the right middle lobe compared to the preoperative findings. We will monitor this closely and take necessary actions if needed. Please make sure to attend your follow-up appointments for further evaluation. Patient: Okay, I understand. Thank you for explaining everything to me, doctor. Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to reach out. Take care and see you at your follow-up appointment. Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help. See you soon

document: Doctor: Hi there, I see you're here for a follow-up visit, have you been experiencing any new or concerning symptoms? Patient: Yes, I've been having a painful, enlarging lump in my left breast for some time now. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Let me perform a clinical examination to better understand the issue. Hmm, I can feel a pulsatile mass with a continuous machinery murmur in the outer upper quadrant of your left breast. We'll need to do a Color Doppler imaging to get a clearer picture of the lump. Patient: Okay, sure. Doctor: Based on the Color Doppler imaging, we found an anechoic lump measuring 45  26  33 mm, fed by an afferent artery. It shows a yin-yang appearance and a biphasic "to-and-fro" pattern. There's also a fistula situated 3-mm proximal to the anechoic lump, connecting the afferent artery and a concomitant vein. Patient: What does that mean? Doctor: Based on these findings, you've been diagnosed with breast PA-AVF. Don't worry, we'll take good care of you. We've consulted with a multidisciplinary team and determined that the lesion poses a risk of rupture. It's recommended that the lesion be excised and ligated under local anesthesia as soon as possible. Patient: I see. How will the procedure be done? Doctor: We'll make a 3-mm operative incision along the direction of the vascular route under ultrasonography guidance. The incision will be at the 1 o'clock position, 7 cm from the nipple, and it'll be concealed to prevent any cosmetic defect. We'll then ligate the proximal and distal artery and vein of the PA-AVF and excise it. Patient: Is the surgery complicated? Doctor: No, the entire operation is quite simple and time-efficient. The mean bleeding volume is only 5 mL, so it's relatively safe. Patient: That's reassuring. When can we schedule the surgery? Doctor: We can schedule it as

I'm going to start you on an empirical antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone (2 g every 12h) and vancomycin (500 mg every 6h). We'll need to run some tests to find out what's causing your symptoms. Patient: Okay, thank you, Doctor. (After the tests and analysis) Doctor: We've received the results of your tests. It appears that you have secondary sepsis caused by meningitis from Streptococcus pneumoniae. Patient: Oh no, that sounds serious. Doctor: Yes, it is a serious condition. document: Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today? Patient: Hi, I've been having this cough for three months now. I haven't traveled outside Djibouti, and I don't have any medical, surgical, or tuberculosis history. Doctor: I see. Let's do a chest radiograph and some tests to determine the cause of your cough. We'll also test you for HIV. (After receiving the test results) Doctor: Your chest radiograph shows a retractile opacity in the right upper lobe of your lung and a para-aortic opacity with micronodules of the culmen. Your HIV test came back negative, which is good news. We also conducted a direct microscopic examination of your sputum smear after Ziehl-Neelsen staining, and it exhibited acid-fast bacilli. However, your sputum was not cultured. Patient: Oh, I see. What does that mean, doc? Doctor: Based on these findings, I'm diagnosing you with pulmonary tuberculosis. We will start you on first-line antituberculosis drugs to treat your condition. Patient: Okay, thank you. (After three months of treatment) Patient: Hi, doc. I'm back, but my symptoms haven't improved. My cough is still persistent. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Let's perform another direct examination of your sputum and a GeneXpert® MTB/RIF lab test to check for any changes. (After receiving the test results) Doctor: Your sputum examination came back positive, and we detected a rifampicin-resistant M. tuberculosis complex isolate. We'll need to hospitalize you and change your treatment plan. Patient: Alright, what's the new treatment plan? Doctor: We'll be treating you with daily doses of kanamycin (1 g), moxifloxacin (400 mg), prothionamide (250 mg), clofazimine (100 mg), isoniazid (300 mg), ethionamide (250 mg), and pyrazinamide (400 mg).

document: Doctor: Hello, I understand you have been diagnosed with kappa light chain multiple myeloma and ESRD. We have treated you with five cycles of CyBorD followed by high-dose cyclophosphamide mobilization and autologous HSCT with melphalan 140 mg/m2 therapy. How are you feeling now? Patient: I've been feeling quite weak, and I recently had a fever. Doctor: I see. It appears that you developed a neutropenic fever with Streptococcus sanguinis bacteremia. We have been treating you with vancomycin, cefazolin, and metronidazole for that infection. Have you had any history of liver disease? Patient: No, I've never had any liver problems before. Doctor: Your total serum bilirubin level was 3.4 mg/dl at the time of transplantation, and it peaked on treatment day 24 at 22 mg/dl. We performed imaging and discovered ascites, which is fluid in your abdominal cavity. We also conducted a liver biopsy on treatment day 16, which was consistent with SOS (sinusoidal obstruction syndrome). Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good. What are the next steps in my treatment? Doctor: We have started treating you with ursodiol, a medication that helps protect the liver. Unfortunately, your condition has worsened, and we were hoping to get defibrotide for you under compassionate use. Patient: So, when can I start the defibrotide treatment? Doctor: I'm sorry to inform you that we were unable to secure the defibrotide in time. Your loved one passed away on treatment day 25. Our deepest condolences to you and your family. Family Member: Thank you, Doctor. We appreciate all the efforts you and your team made to help him.

Doctor: Based on your presentation, it is possible that you have Cushing's syndrome. We'll need to run some tests to confirm this. Patient: Okay, what kind of tests? Doctor: We'll check for ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome, which could be due to a pituitary tumor. In your case, your symptoms and test results confirmed ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome, likely of pituitary etiology. Patient: Oh wow, so what's the next step? Doctor: The next step was a transsphenoidal surgery to remove the tumor. During your first surgery, the tumor was visualized but no sample was obtained for pathological analysis. Patient: Yeah, I remember that. So what happened after that? Doctor: With persistent postoperative hypercortisolism, a repeat transsphenoidal surgery was completed two months later. This time, a corticotroph adenoma was confirmed on pathology. Patient: But I still felt off after the second surgery... Doctor: Yes, you remained hypercortisolemic after the second surgery. One year later, we started you on cabergoline 1 mg twice weekly for persistent and moderately elevated 24-hour UFC levels. Patient: Oh, I see. But I had to stop taking the medication for a while... Doctor: At age 54, during a period of medication nonadherence, your 24-hour UFC increased to twice normal. document: Doctor: Hello, welcome to the Department of Conservative Dentistry and Endodontics at SGT Dental College. How can I help you today? Patient: Hi, I've been experiencing severe pain in my right lower back tooth region for the last three days. The pain comes and goes, but it gets worse when I eat or drink something hot. Doctor: I see. Let's do a clinical evaluation to find out what's causing the pain. (After evaluation) Doctor: It appears that you have secondary caries associated with your restored right mandibular first molar. We'll need to take a diagnostic radiograph to get a better view. (After radiograph) Doctor: The radiograph shows restoration close to the pulp and the presence of an additional root. We took another radiograph at 30-degree mesial and distal angulation to confirm this. We'll need to perform an access cavity preparation under local anesthesia using an endo access bur from Dentsply, Switzerland. Patient: Okay, what's the next step after that? Doctor: We'll locate the first distal canal towards the buccal side, which indicates the presence of one additional canal on the lingual side. The shape of the access cavity will be modified from triangular to trapezoidal to locate the fourth canal. A DG-16 endodontic explorer will be used to locate the root canal orifices, and a 15 # K-file from Mani, Japan will be used to establish patency of the canals. Patient: Got it. How do you determine the working length? Doctor: We'll determine the working length using an apex locator, Root ZX from J. Morita, and reconfirm it radiographically. Biomechanical preparation will be done with a rotary ProTaper Next file system from Dentsply, Switzerland. Patient: What will you use for irrigation during the procedure? Doctor: During instrumentation, we'll use 1.3% sodium hypochlorite as an irrigant and 17% EDTA as the final flush. Patient: And how will you perform the obturation? Doctor: We'll perform the obturation with gutta-percha points using a cold lateral condensation technique. After that, we'll restore the access cavity with composite resin

document: Doctor: Hi there, I see you've presented to the emergency department with abdominal pain that's been going on for one night. This pain has been causing you difficulty with sleeping and walking, is that correct? Patient: Yeah, that's right. It's been really hard to get any rest or move around. Doctor: Have you experienced any loss of appetite, vomiting, or fever along with this pain? Patient: No, I haven't lost my appetite or been vomiting, but I did have a fever earlier. Doctor: I noticed that you had an appendectomy 19 months ago due to similar symptoms and were diagnosed with appendicitis. Were there any complications during or after that surgery? Patient: No, there weren't any problems during or after the surgery. Doctor: Have you had a bowel movement in the last few days? Patient: Hmm, now that you mention it, I haven't had one for several days. Doctor: When you first arrived, we performed a physical examination and found signs of fever and localized peritonitis. document: Doctor: Hello, I understand you're an 8-year-old female patient who was diagnosed with congenital heart disease during infancy, but had unknown follow-up and treatment. What brings you here today? Patient: I've been feeling really tired and having trouble breathing when I'm playing with my friends. It started about a month ago. Doctor: I see. When you were admitted to the hospital, we did a physical examination and found a systolic murmur in your left para-sternum. An echocardiography was also performed, revealing a peri-membranous VSD with a diameter of 12 mm, left to right shunting, and a pressure gradient of 20 mmHg. Additionally, we found a PDA with a diameter of 4 mm. Patient: Oh, that sounds serious. What did you do to treat it? Doctor: First, we performed a trans-catheter PDA closure. Then, 3 weeks later, we did a TES for VSD repair without robotic assistance. During the procedure, you were placed in a supine position with your arms along your body, under general anesthesia with a single-lumen endotracheal tube. Patient: What else did you do during the surgery? Doctor: We used a no.6 Knitted Dacron graft to connect your right common FA with an end-to-side anastomosis. The other side of the graft was connected to the arterial line of the cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) machine. We also inserted SVC and IVC cannulae via your internal jugular vein (IJV) and femoral vein, respectively, using the Seldinger technique. Patient: And then what happened? Doctor: When we started the CPB, your arterial pressure gradually increased to 260 mmHg. So, we switched to bilateral FA cannulation by inserting an additional 10Fr FA cannula directly into your left common FA. After that, your arterial pressure declined and stabilized at 180-200 mmHg. Patient: How did you perform the surgery? Doctor: We placed four soft trocars in the right side of your chest to assist with the procedure. Patient: I see. Thank you for explaining

document: Doctor: Hi there, I understand you've been brought to the emergency department due to sudden weakness and respiratory distress. Can you tell me more about how you're feeling? Patient: Yeah, I suddenly felt really weak and it's hard to breathe. My consciousness feels confused too. Doctor: I see. We've noticed that you have areflexic acute flaccid paralysis present on all four extremities. We've conducted some laboratory tests to better understand your condition. Your erythrocyte sedimentation rate is slightly elevated at 21 mm/h, compared to the average of 15 mm/h. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Your blood count, acetylcholine receptor antibody, thyroid function tests, and other laboratory findings are all within the normal range. However, there are no cells present in your cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), and the CSF protein is high at 65 mg/dL. Patient: Hmm, what does that mean, doc? Doctor: These findings could suggest some sort of neurological issue. On the second day of your hospitalization, you developed bilateral peripheral facial paralysis. Additionally, nerve conduction studies showed a decrease in the sensory and motor action potentials of your upper extremities, with increased distal latencies. Patient: That sounds serious. Doctor: It is quite concerning. We also couldn't obtain any combined muscle action potential (CMAP) from your bilateral peroneal-tibial nerves or sural nerve sensory action potential. To help you, we decided to perform plasma exchange every other day, for a total of three times due to your respiratory distress. Patient: Oh, I see. Doctor: Unfortunately, you developed resistant hypotension as an autonomic dysfunction, along with pulmonary infections. We tried our best to control the hypotension, but it persisted. Patient: Oh no... Doctor: I'm sorry to inform you that your condition worsened and you experienced cardiac arrest on the sixth day of your hospitalization. Despite our efforts, we were unable to save you. Patient's Family: We appreciate your efforts, doctor. We understand that you did everything you could. Thank you for trying.

document: Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today? Patient: Hi, I've been having some right-sided loin pain and I noticed some microscopic hematuria, but I don't have any urinary symptoms. Doctor: I see, let's run some routine blood tests to check your renal function and perform an ultrasound scan of your urinary tract to see if there might be any issues. Patient: Okay, that sounds good. [After tests and scan] Doctor: Your blood tests show a derangement in your renal function and the ultrasound scan revealed right-sided hydronephrosis. We need to do a further computed tomography (CT) scan of your kidneys, ureters, and bladder to get a clearer picture of what's going on. Patient: Alright, let's do it. [After CT scan] Doctor: The CT scan showed a dilatation of the ureter up to the vesicoureteric junction with an associated tight stricture. We'll need to perform a right rigid ureteroscopy, ureteric biopsy, and ureteric stent insertion to get a better understanding of the issue. Patient: Okay, I understand. [After procedure] Doctor: The histology report from the biopsy shows that you have transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter. Initially, we didn't perform any neuroendocrine markers because the tumor didn't show any classical signs of a carcinoid tumor or a well-differentiated small cell carcinoma. However, further examination revealed an atypical carcinoid pattern. Patient: Oh no, that doesn't sound good. Doctor: We did some further imaging of your chest and fortunately, we didn't find any distant metastases. Our plan is to perform a right laparoscopic nephroureterectomy and open excision of the bladder cuff to remove the tumor. Patient: I'm glad there's a plan in place. Let's do what needs to be done. [After surgery] Doctor: The surgery went well. The tumor in your ureter was about 18 mm long, and we were able to achieve a clear resection margin of at least 4 mm. document: Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today? Patient: Hi, I'm a 19-year-old female and I recently got a dental implant. I went to my orthodontist because I was having some problems with it. Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about the complications you've experienced? Patient: Well, my jaw has been hurting, and it feels like there's something wrong with the implant area. Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. We performed a biopsy to better understand what's going on, and it confirmed that you have central giant cell granuloma (CGCG) of the jaw. Patient: Oh no, that sounds serious. What can we do about it? Doctor: Don't worry, we've started you on a treatment called denosumab. You'll be receiving 120 mg monthly. It should help with your condition. Patient: Okay, that's good to know. How will we keep track of my progress? Doctor: We'll be conducting surveillance to monitor your condition. If you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to reach out. Take care and see you at your next appointment.

document: Doctor: Hi there, I understand you've come to the emergency department with some pain in your abdomen. Can you tell me more about your symptoms? Patient: Yeah, for the past two days, I've had this pain in my stomach, and I haven't been feeling like eating. I've also been vomiting. Doctor: I see. Based on your presentation, it's important that we conduct a thorough examination. Let me examine your abdomen. Patient: Sure, go ahead. Doctor: (After examination) It seems you have pain and tenderness on the right side of your abdomen. We'll need to run some clinical, laboratory, and radiological tests to determine the cause. Patient: Okay, I hope it's nothing serious. Doctor: (After tests) We've found that you've tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 through a PCR test of your nasopharyngeal swab. In addition, based on your symptoms and our examination, we suspect that you may have appendicitis. Patient: Oh no, what will happen now? Doctor: We will start you on an empiric intravenous antimicrobial treatment with cefotaxime and metronidazole to help fight the infection. Additionally, you'll need to undergo a laparoscopic appendectomy in the operating room to remove your appendix. Patient: How soon will I have the surgery? Doctor: We will take you to the operating room as soon as possible, as this is an emergency case. Patient: Alright then, I hope everything goes well. Doctor: Rest assured, our team will take good care of you. We perform appendectomies routinely, and we'll monitor you closely during the procedure and afterwards. Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.

No additional lab values or imaging results provided. The presence of right-sided abdominal tenderness and systemic symptoms such as vomiting support the diagnosis of appendicitis. Plan: The patient will be started on empiric intravenous antimicrobial treatment with cefotaxime and metronidazole. A laparoscopic appendectomy is scheduled urgently to remove the inflamed appendix. Post-operative care will include monitoring for complications and managing COVID-19 symptoms as necessary. The patient will be educated about the procedures and expected post-operative course.

document: Doctor: Hi, I understand that you've presented to our hand and peripheral nerve clinic 4 months after an attempted Nexplanon® removal from your left arm. Can you tell me more about that experience? Patient: Yeah, my nurse practitioner tried to remove it, but neither of us was able to feel the Nexplanon® before the removal. They didn't do any imaging studies to confirm its location. Doctor: I see. So, what happened during the removal attempt? Patient: They injected some local anesthetic and made a small incision at the site of insertion. But they couldn't find the Nexplanon® right away. After exploring the area, the NP grabbed something in my arm, and I felt an "electric shock" sensation that went down to my medial elbow as they pulled on it. Doctor: Oh, I'm sorry to hear that. What happened after the removal attempt? Patient: I had complete numbness in my small and ring fingers. I went back to my NP for a follow-up, but the numbness didn't improve over time. I also started to notice my hand muscles wasting away and my grip getting weaker. Doctor: That's concerning. Did your NP order any tests to investigate this issue? Patient: Yes, they ordered a nerve conduction study almost 4 months after the attempted removal. The results showed a 50% loss of ulnar nerve function. Doctor: Based on your presentation, it appears that you have a severe, chronic ulnar nerve injury. On examination, I can see the classic signs: wasting of the ulnar nerve-innervated intrinsic muscles of your hand, a claw position of your ring and small fingers, and dense numbness in an ulnar sensory nerve distribution. I also noticed a well-healed incision with surrounding scar tissue from the extraction attempt. Can you feel the Nexplanon® in your arm now? Patient: No, I still can't feel it. Doctor: We took some X-rays, and they showed the radio-opaque Nexplanon® at the junction of the proximal and middle thirds of your humeral shaft, with the most distal end 16.5 cm proximal to the medial epicondyle. Patient: Oh

document: Doctor: Hello, I'm Dr. Smith. I understand you have a history of CTEPH and are here for a PTE procedure. How are you feeling today? Patient: Hi, Dr. Smith. I'm a bit nervous but ready to get this done. Doctor: I understand. During the rewarming process following your PTE, we noticed bright red blood in your airway. We performed a bronchoscopy and found that there was bleeding from your right lung. Patient: Oh no, that sounds scary. Doctor: It was concerning, but we attempted to control the bleeding by placing a right-sided Arndt endobronchial blocker. Unfortunately, due to copious bleeding, our first attempt was unsuccessful. Patient: What happened next? Doctor: We exchanged your 8.0 mm single lumen ETT for a 9 mm single lumen ETT. Then, we were able to successfully place a right-sided 9Fr Arndt endobronchial blocker with the aid of a 6.0 mm outer diameter therapeutic bronchoscope. This helped contain the bleeding. Patient: That's a relief. Doctor: We continued weaning you off the cardiopulmonary bypass, and everything went well. You were then transferred to the ICU for close monitoring. Patient: So, what's next for me? Doctor: Unfortunately, your postoperative course has been complicated by renal failure, reintubation for hemoptysis, and poor neurologic recovery. Due to these multiple complications, we have been discussing the best course of action with your family. Patient's family: Doctor, what options do we have for him? Doctor: At this point, we are considering initiating comfort only measures to ensure that he is as comfortable as possible during this difficult time. Patient's family: We understand. We want him to be comfortable. Doctor: I'm sorry to say, but despite our best efforts, the patient expired on postoperative day 20. Our condolences to the family, and we will continue to provide support as needed.

They prescribed intermittent non-steroid anti-inflammatory drugs, some injections, but I don't know the exact drug, and physical therapy. document: Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today? Patient: Hi, doctor. I'm experiencing sudden epigastric pain, and I feel like I'm in shock. Doctor: I see. In that case, let me check your vital signs. We need to find out what's causing this shock. Have you had any recent medical issues? Patient: Yes, I was hospitalized a month ago in your department and underwent a patch repair for a gastric ulcer perforation. Doctor: Alright, let's perform a contrast-enhanced CT scan to get more information. (After CT scan) Doctor: The CT scan revealed a retroperitoneal hematoma in your pancreatic head, aneurysm formation in the PDA, and extraluminal compression to the celiac trunk. Extravasation was also detected around the aneurysm in the PDA, but no liquid was retained in your peritoneal cavity. Patient: Oh, that sounds serious. What should we do? Doctor: We will perform an emergent IVR for hemostasis to address the retroperitoneal hemorrhage from the ruptured PDA aneurysm. Arteriography of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) will be done through a sheath introduced in your right femoral artery. Patient: Okay, go ahead. (After the procedure) Doctor: The imaging of the SMA revealed the development of several collaterals in your pancreatic head, and the common and proper hepatic arteries were imaged via these collaterals. The aneurysm in your PDA had leakage of the contrast-enhanced agent with a diameter of 9.3 mm. We have completed the IVR hemostasis by performing PDA coil embolization. Patient: So, what's next? Doctor: We will conduct SMA arteriography to see the other collaterals perfusing your proper hepatic artery. After the IVR therapy, we will monitor your blood chemical analysis for several weeks to ensure that your transaminase level is not elevated and hepatic infarction is negative. Patient: Got it. And what about the obstruction caused by the hematoma? Doctor: We observed obstruction of

document: Doctor: Hi there, I understand you're a 13-year-old girl who has been experiencing abdominal pain and bloody stool. Can you tell me more about how long this has been happening and how it's been progressing? Patient: Yeah, I started having abdominal pain about 3 months ago. At first, it wasn't too bad and would come and go, so I didn't see a doctor. But lately, the pain has gotten worse, and I've been having bloody stool more often. Doctor: I see. We performed an imaging study and it showed that there's a mass, including a fecalith, occupying your pelvic and right lower abdominal cavity (Fig.). Based on this, we made a preoperative diagnosis of an acute appendicitis with an appendiceal mass (Fig.). We've already done drainage of the abscess and an appendectomy. Patient: Oh, okay. So what did you find during the procedure? Doctor: Although the body of your appendix looked intact, as well as your ileum and cecum, the histopathological examination revealed PAA in the tip of the resected appendix. Because of this, we have planned a radical operation for the residual tumor of PAA in your pelvic cavity. Patient: What does that operation involve? Doctor: It involves a whole mass resection and ileocecal resection with lymph node dissection. In the first operation, we speculate that we removed the body of your appendix but left most of the mass and the tip of the appendix. So in the second operation, we will remove the mass that was derived from the tip of your appendix. Patient: Will you need to remove any other organs? Doctor: Unfortunately, yes. The masses are tightly adherent with infiltration into your sigmoid colon, uterus, and right ovary. We will need to remove these organs, and then perform a subsequent sigmoid colostomy (Fig.). However, we will preserve your left ovary to maintain your fertility. Patient: What were the results of the pathological examination? Doctor: The pathological findings demonstrated negative margins and no lymph node invasions. Your final pathological stage is pT4(S

document: Doctor: Hello, can you please tell me about your past medical history? Patient: Actually, I don't have any significant past medical history. Doctor: Alright. Can you tell me what happened prior to your admission here? Patient: I'm not sure. I just moved from Puerto Rico three weeks ago, and then I was found unresponsive at home with foamy secretions around my mouth. Doctor: I see. You were found apneic and pulseless, so the paramedics performed cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) on you. After prolonged CPR, you had the return of spontaneous circulation and were admitted to the ICU. We started you on therapeutic hypothermia as well. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Your urine toxicology showed the presence of cocaine, benzodiazepines, and cannabinoids. The most likely cause of your cardiac arrest was thought to be an overdose. Patient: Oh, I see. Doctor: We also initiated antibiotics, vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam, along with vasopressors for septic shock. You were put on mechanical ventilation and intubation for respiratory failure. We also did a Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of your brain, which showed diffuse injury and restricted diffusion involving both basal ganglia, bilateral frontal, and occipital cortices. Patient: That sounds serious. Doctor: Yes, it is. You continued to have repeated episodes of decerebrate posturing, rhythmic jaw movements, sweating, fever, and tachycardia. document: Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today? Patient: Hi, I've been having some right-sided chest pain lately. Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about your medical history? Patient: Well, I've been diabetic for about 4 years now and I'm also hypertensive. I've been on treatment for both. Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. Do you have any other medical concerns or history? Patient: Yeah, I've had primary amenorrhoea, but it was never investigated before. Doctor: Okay. Let's do a physical examination. Please step on the scale and measure your height. Patient: Alright, I weigh 58 kg and I'm 155 cm tall. Doctor: Thank you. Now let me check your blood pressure and examine your secondary sexual characteristics. Patient: Okay, sure. Doctor: Your blood pressure seems to be normal, and your secondary sexual characteristics are also normal. Now, I'm going to listen to your breathing. Please take deep breaths for me. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Hmm, I noticed that there are absent breath sounds on the right side of your chest, and it appears there is a mediastinal shift to the right as well. Patient: What does that mean, doc? Doctor: The absence of breath sounds on the right side of your chest could indicate a problem with your lungs, and the mediastinal shift to the right may be related to that issue. We need to investigate this further and find out the cause of your chest pain. I recommend scheduling some tests as soon as possible. Patient: Oh, okay. What tests do you recommend? Doctor: We'll start with a chest X-ray and some blood tests to get a better understanding of the underlying cause. Based on the results, we may need to perform additional tests or start treatment. Patient: I understand. I'll schedule the tests as soon as I can. Doctor: That's great. Please keep me updated on the results, and don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions or if your symptoms worsen. Patient: Will do, doc. Thanks for your help. Doctor: You're welcome, and take care.

document: Doctor: Good morning, Mr. Tanaka. I see from your medical history that you have hypertension, dyslipidemia, and peripheral vascular disease. Can you tell me about any symptoms you're experiencing? Patient: Good morning, Doctor. I've been experiencing some chest discomfort and shortness of breath lately. Doctor: I understand. When you were 71, you had a successful endovascular treatment for your occlusive right common iliac artery. At that time, we performed transthoracic echocardiography for screening, which revealed a dilated aortic root with a width of 49 mm. Do you remember that? Patient: Yes, I remember. Doctor: We also did an electrocardiogram-gated cardiac computed tomography (EG-CT) that revealed two sinus of Valsalva aneurysms (SVAs) in both the left and right coronary sinuses, with no obstruction to surrounding cardiac structures. The sizes of the SVAs were 27.2 mm and 33.1 mm for the left and right sides, respectively. Due to their relatively small size, we decided to observe them carefully for 5 years. Patient: Right, I've been coming in for regular check-ups. Doctor: I appreciate your diligence. In your recent follow-up EG-CT, we noticed that the sizes of the SVAs had grown to 34.5 mm and 35.7 mm, respectively. The transthoracic echocardiography also showed moderate aortic regurgitation. The SVA in the left coronary sinus has grown between the pulmonary artery and the left atrium, bulging out on the anterior surface of the heart. The SVA in the right coronary sinus has also grown, pressing the right ventricular outflow tract. Patient: That doesn't sound good. Doctor: We concluded that both SVAs are extracardiac, meaning they're expanding on the surface of the heart. This type has a relatively high risk of rupture, which could be life-threatening. Given this situation, I recommend that you undergo surgery for SVA removal. Patient: I see. What does the surgery involve? document: Doctor: Hello, I see you've presented to our pancreas multidisciplinary clinic. What seems to be the issue? Patient: Hi, Doctor. For the past 2 months, I've been experiencing some generalized bloating and epigastric discomfort. Doctor: I see. In that case, we should perform a computed tomography (CT) scan to get a better look at what might be causing your symptoms. (After the CT scan) Doctor: Your CT scan results have come back, and they demonstrated an 11.2  9.6 cm heterogeneous solid appearing mass in the tail of your pancreas. The mass has several small peripheral calcifications and lobulated contours abutting your spleen, stomach, and splenic flexure of colon. However, there doesn't seem to be any direct invasion. Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good. What do we do now? Doctor: We will need to perform a distal pancreatectomy and splenectomy with splenic artery lymph node dissection to remove the mass. (After the surgery) Doctor: The surgery went well. Intraoperatively, we observed a large soft lobular cystic mass at the pancreatic tail. The mass was locally contained without any obvious invasion of surrounding structures or gross metastasis. We sent it for histopathological assessment. Patient: What were the results of the assessment? Doctor: The assessment established it as a pT3pN0pMx SPNP (CD56pos nuclear -cateninpos chromograninneg and synaptophysinneg). Margins were negative, and there was no lymphovascular or perineural invasion. You'll be discharged home after a period of convalescence in the hospital. Patient: Thank you, Doctor. (Four years later) Doctor: I see you've been referred back to our clinic after a biopsy-proven recurrence in the splenic fossa. We will need to perform additional surgery to remove the tumor. Patient: What will the surgery involve? Doctor: We'll need to perform a wedge gastrectomy and partial colectomy to resect the tumor, as it is densely adherent

Recurrence involved a tumor densely adherent to the splenic flexure, gastric fundus, left diaphragm, left kidney, and left adrenal gland. Pathology confirmed recurrent metastatic SPNP in the omentum

document: Doctor: Hi, I heard you were referred to our clinic due to sudden visual loss in your right eye. Can you tell me more about what happened? Let's check your vision. *After checking* Your best-corrected visual acuity is 20/200 in your right eye and 20/20 in your left eye. There is a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) in your right eye, as well as color vision deficiency and scotoma. Patient: What does that mean? Doctor: It means that there's an issue with the nerve response in your right eye, and you're having trouble with color and a blind spot in your vision. Now, let's do a funduscopic examination. *After the exam* I found swelling in your right optic disc, with superonasal flame-shaped hemorrhaging, venous congestion, and tortuosity. Patient: Is my left eye okay? Doctor: Yes, your left eye appears normal, with a cup-to-disc ratio of less than 0.1, suggesting a "disc-at-risk." Patient: What's the treatment for that? document: Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today? Patient: Hi, Doctor. I recently had a distal pancreatectomy and splenectomy to treat a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor. I'm here for a follow-up. Doctor: I see. How have you been feeling since the surgery? Patient: In the immediate postoperative period, I developed a pancreatic fluid leak from the tail of my pancreas, and an abdominal drain was placed. Doctor: Did the leakage stop after the drain was placed? Patient: Yes, it stopped draining eventually, and the drain was removed. Doctor: Were there any further complications after the drain removal? Patient: Actually, yes. A month after the drain removal, a CT scan showed an increase in the size of the rim enhancing fluid collection around the tail of my pancreas. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Did you undergo any further procedures to address this issue? Patient: Yes, an ERCP was performed for the suspected pancreatic duct leak, and it confirmed a leak from the tail of my pancreas. Doctor: What was the next step in your treatment? Patient: The doctor performed an endoscopic pancreatic sphincterotomy and placed a 5 Fr x 13 cm pancreatic duct stent with internal barbs. Doctor: Good. And did you have any additional imaging done after that procedure? Patient: Yes, an EUS showed a well-demarcated, hypoechoic, heterogeneous collection adjacent to the tail of the pancreas, about 6.5 cm in the largest dimension. Doctor: How was this collection addressed? Patient: The doctor placed a 15 mm x 10 mm LAMS under endosonographic guidance from my stomach into the fluid collection, and a large amount of pus was drained. Doctor: It sounds like the procedure was successful. Did you have any follow-up scans to check the progress? Patient: Yes, a CT scan of my abdomen a month later showed a decrease in the size of the previously demonstrated LUQ rim-enhancing fluid collection. Doctor: That's a positive sign. Were there any other complications or events following the CT scan? Patient: Unfortunately, I had a neurological event before the stent

Additional imaging showed enlarged, hypoechoic, heterogeneous collection around the head of his abdomen, with an EUS, which confirmed the presence of LUQ, the previous neurological event prior to the surgery. An ERCP was performed for the suspected Pancreatic duct leak. MRI revealed an increased volume of pus. CT scanning of abdomen showed decreased the size of previously demonstrated LOQ. The patients had previously reported neurological events.

ERCP confirmed a pancreatic duct leak. EU

document: Doctor: Hello, I understand you had a laryngectomy and free flap reconstruction 20 years ago and have been using a prosthesis since then. Can you tell me what happened recently? Patient: Yeah, doc. I was cleaning my prosthesis when it suddenly dislodged and I think I aspirated it. Doctor: I see. How did you feel when that happened? Patient: I started feeling really short of breath and needed supplemental oxygen just to maintain my saturations above 90%. So, I went to the hospital. Doctor: It seems like you initially presented to an outside hospital. They did a CT chest which demonstrated a radiopaque foreign body in your right mainstem bronchus. That's why they transferred you to our emergency department for a higher level of care. Is that correct? Patient: Yes, that's right. Doctor: Our otolaryngology service evaluated you in the emergency department. We performed a bedside flexible bronchoscopy using an Olympus BF-H190 bronchoscope after applying topical lidocaine spray. We found the aspirated prosthesis in your right mainstem bronchus. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: We were able to remove the prosthesis atraumatically by grasping it with flexible biopsy forceps and then withdrawing the entire bronchoscope. There were no other injuries or remaining foreign bodies. Did you feel any relief after that? Patient: Yes, doc. I felt immediate relief after the procedure. Doctor: That's great to hear. We placed a red rubber catheter through your tracheoesophageal puncture to stent the tract. You were then discharged home. You have a follow-up appointment with your speech-language pathologist (SLP) for prosthesis replacement the next day. Please ensure you attend that appointment. Patient: Sure, doc. Thank you so much for your help.
prediction: Subjective: The patient had a laryngectomy and free flap reconstruction 20 years ago and has been using the prosthesis since then. He had to use supplemental oxygen to maintain saturations above 90%. Initially, the patient presented to an outside hospital for an emergency department for higher level of care. The otolaryngology service evaluated him in the Emergency Department. They performed bedside flexible bronchoscopy using an Olympus BF-H190 after applying topical lidocaine spray and found the aspirated prosthetic in his right mainstem in right Main lungs. There were no other injuries or remaining foreign bodies.
summarization: Subjective: The patient, a long-term laryngectomy and free flap reconstruction patient, reported that while cleaning his prosthesis, it dislodged and was aspirated. He experienced significant shortness of breath and required supplemental oxygen to maintain oxygen saturations above 90%. Objective: Initial evaluation at an outside hospital revealed a radiopaque foreign body in the right mainstem bronchus on CT chest. At our facility, a bedside flexible bronchoscopy performed by the otolaryngology service using an Olympus BF-H190 bronchoscope and topical lidocaine spray confirmed the presence of the aspirated prosthesis in the right mainstem bronchus. The prosthesis was successfully removed atraumatically using flexible biopsy forceps. Post-procedure, no injuries or remaining foreign bodies were noted. Assessment: The primary diagnosis is aspiration of a tracheoesophageal prosthesis. The successful removal of the prosthesis without any complications indicates a positive immediate outcome. There is no evidence of additional complications such as infection or significant mucosal injury at this time

document: Doctor: Hello, I see that you're a 67-year-old male chronic smoker with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. What brings you in today? Patient: Yeah, doc. I had a CT scan recently, and they found a lung nodule. They said it might be malignant and now they want to do a biopsy. Doctor: That's correct. We've admitted you for an imaging guided biopsy of the 1.2 cm left lower lobe lung nodule that was found on your computed tomography scan. It is indeed suspicious for lung malignancy, so we need to investigate further. Patient: Okay, so what's the plan for this biopsy? Doctor: We will place you in a prone position and visualize the lung parenchyma in the posterior lateral left chest. Under CT guidance, we'll use a 19-gauge guide to obtain two separate 20-gauge core biopsy specimens from the mass. Patient: Hmm, sounds a bit complicated. Are there any risks? Doctor: There's always a small risk of complications, such as hemorrhage. But we'll be monitoring you closely throughout the procedure to ensure your safety. Patient: Alright, let's do it then. [After the biopsy procedure] Doctor: The biopsy went well, and there was no hemorrhage or immediate post-procedure complications. However, towards the end of the procedure, you started complaining of chest pain and became unconscious. We couldn't find any palpable pulses, so we called a code blue and began cardiopulmonary resuscitation according to Advanced Cardiovascular Life Support guidelines. Patient: Oh my, what happened next? Doctor: You demonstrated ventricular fibrillation, which responded to defibrillation shock and epinephrine. We performed three cycles of chest compressions, administered one dose of epinephrine, and delivered a shock of 200 J. You were successfully resuscitated and intubated for mechanical ventilation. Patient: Wow, that sounds intense. What caused all that? Doctor: A CT scan of the chest after the resuscitation showed development of a small anechoic area in the left cardiac ventricle, consistent with an air embolus

document: Doctor: Hello, I just wanted to inform you about your son's situation after the accident. He was presented to the emergency department following a high-speed front-end collision with another vehicle. Was he the one driving? Family: No, he was in the front seat but not driving. He was restrained, thankfully. Doctor: I see. The vehicle he was in was struck head-on. Do you happen to know the speed at the time of the collision? Family: We were told it was in excess of 79 miles per hour. Doctor: Yes, that's correct. When your son arrived at the hospital, he was unconscious and not breathing independently. Our team attempted intubation at the scene, but unfortunately, it was unsuccessful. Family: Oh no... So what happened next? Doctor: Sadly, your son was pronounced dead soon after arrival to the hospital. Our deepest condolences to your family. Family: Thank you, Doctor. This is so difficult for us. What were the findings from the radiographs? Doctor: The radiographs at the time of the incident noted internal decapitation with AO assimilation specifically between the anterior arch of the atlas and the basiocciput. No fractures were noted, including the odontoid process. Family: Did he have any past medical or surgical history that could have contributed to this? Doctor: There was no known past medical or surgical history, and the AO assimilation was unknown to your family. The severity of the collision was the primary factor in this tragic outcome. Family: We had no idea about the AO assimilation. Thank you for explaining everything to us, Doctor. Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any further questions or need any support, please don't hesitate to reach out to us. Our thoughts are with you and your family during this difficult time.

document: Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today? Patient: Hi, I've been experiencing some issues like ataxia, tremor, and seizures lately. I'm also worried about my developmental delay. Doctor: I see. Let's first take a look at your electroencephalogram and other test results to better understand your situation. Have you had those tests done? Patient: Yes, I have the report right here. Doctor: Great, let me take a look. Hmm, it shows that your blood ammonia level was >300 g/dL, which is quite high as the normal range is below 80. Your ornithine levels were 71-86 M/dL, and homocitrulline levels were 510-643 M/24 hours. Both of these are also above the normal range. Patient: Oh no, that doesn't sound good. Doctor: Don't worry, we can manage this. I'm going to prescribe you a diet consisting of lactulose, arginine, and protein restriction. This should help in reducing your blood ammonia levels and improving your clinical symptoms. Patient: Okay, I'll follow the diet. How long should I expect before seeing any improvement? Doctor: It may take some time, but you should see a reduction in your blood ammonia levels to around 110-140 g/dL, and you'll likely experience some clinical improvement. Patient: That's good to hear. I have some more news, I recently found out that I'm pregnant, about 8 weeks along. Doctor: Congratulations! In that case, we'll need to adjust your dietary protein intake. I'll be increasing it to 1.2-1.3 g/kg/d to ensure proper nutrition for both you and the baby. Patient: Thank you! I'll make sure to follow the new diet plan. Doctor: I'm glad to hear that. Let's fast forward a bit. You've had a healthy male infant delivered at 39 weeks' gestation. Congratulations once again! Patient: Thank you! Was the delivery okay? Doctor: Yes, the mode of delivery was not disclosed, but during the delivery, your maternal ammonia levels varied from 74 to 215 g/dL. Patient: I hope my child will be okay.

Ornithine levels were 71-86 M/dL, and homocitrulline levels were 510-643 M/24 hours, both above normal ranges. During pregnancy, her ammonia levels varied from 74 to 215 g/dL. Post-delivery, her child's development was monitored, showing normal development at 16 months and an IQ of 130 at age 5. Assessment: The primary diagnosis is a metabolic disorder characterized by elevated ammonia, ornithine, and homocitrulline levels, likely urea cycle disorder. Differential diagnoses could include other metabolic or genetic disorders affecting ammonia metabolism. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic with adherence to dietary management, though close monitoring is

document: Doctor: Hi there, I see that you've presented to our emergency department with complaints of nausea and vomiting for four days. I'm sorry to hear that. Patient: Yes, it's been really difficult to deal with. Doctor: I understand you were diagnosed with right-sided, multicentric, infiltrating lobular carcinoma of the breast 10 years ago. You were Stage 1A, estrogen receptor positive (ER+), progesterone receptor positive (PR+), and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 negative (HER2-). Is that correct? Patient: Hmm, yes, that's right. Doctor: And you had a right mastectomy, with sentinel lymph nodes sampled during surgery, which were negative for metastases. You were also treated with adjuvant anastrozole for five years, and yearly mammograms have been negative for recurrence. Is that accurate? Patient: Yes, that's correct. Doctor: I see that one year prior to this presentation, you were evaluated at our hospital for similar complaints of nausea and vomiting. A computed tomography (CT) scan of your abdomen and pelvis on admission revealed a mass-like thickening of the gastric antrum and distension of the proximal stomach. Do you remember that? Patient: Yes, I do. Doctor: An upper endoscopy (EGD) was performed, which revealed esophagitis and gastric stenosis. This was dilated using a through-the-scope controlled radial expansion (CRE) balloon, without fluoroscopic guidance. Biopsy of the gastric stenosis revealed gastric mucosa of antral type with minimal chronic inactive gastritis. No morphologic evidence of a Helicobacter pylori infection was detected. Did your symptoms of nausea and vomiting improve following balloon dilation? Patient: Yes, they did improve after that. Doctor: Good to hear. You were discharged on a daily proton pump inhibitor. document: Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today? Patient: Hi, I have Crouzon syndrome and I've been having multiple episodes of epistaxis in the past few days. I also have nasal obstruction and impaired nasal breathing for the past few months. Doctor: I see. Do you have any other medical history we should be aware of? Patient: No, the rest of my medical history is free. Doctor: Alright, let's start with a clinical examination. *Examines patient* I notice a polypoid lesion protruding from your right nostril, asymmetry of your face, and projection of the ipsilateral canine fossa. Patient: What does that mean? Doctor: We'll need to perform a computed tomography of your paranasal sinuses to get a clearer picture of what's going on. *Reviews CT results* The CT shows an inhomogeneous soft-tissue mass that completely occupies your right nasal cavity, maxillary sinus, and anterior and posterior ethmoidal cells. The lesion has caused extensive bone remodeling of your right maxillary sinus with complete absence of its anterior wall, erosion of the posterior wall, and entry of the lesion in the pterygopalatine fossa. There's also erosion of the ipsilateral lower and median orbital wall, and entry of the lesion in the orbital cavity. Despite its large size, the lesion seems to be well-defined without invasive characteristics. Patient: That sounds serious. What do the laboratory tests say? Doctor: Your routine laboratory tests are within the normal range. We also had a preoperative maxillofacial consultation, which excluded pathology of odontogenic origin. Patient: What's the next step, then? Doctor: We'll have you undergo a biopsy under local anesthesia. *Performs biopsy* The findings show nonspecific inflammation. We'll need to perform open surgery under general anesthesia via lateral rhinotomy and medial maxillectomy. Patient: Okay, let's do it. *After surgery* Doctor: The surgery went well. The maxillary sinus mucosa was completely replaced by inflammatory tissue, which we were able to mobilize and dissect free from surrounding tissues

summarization: Subjective: Patient with Crouzon syndrome presents with multiple episodes of epistaxis over the past few days and chronic nasal obstruction with impaired nasal breathing for several months. No other significant medical history reported. Objective: Clinical examination revealed a polypoid lesion protruding from the right nostril, facial asymmetry, and projection of the ipsilateral canine fossa. CT imaging showed an inhomogeneous soft-tissue mass occupying the right nasal cavity, maxillary sinus, and ethmoidal cells, with extensive bone remodeling and erosion but no invasive characteristics. Routine lab tests are within normal limits. Biopsy indicated nonspecific inflammation. Postoperative findings confirmed nasal polyposis with inflammation but no fungal invasion or macroscopic neighboring structure invasion. Assessment: Primary diagnosis of extensive nasal polyposis secondary to Crouzon syndrome, complicated by significant structural changes in the nasal cavity and surrounding areas. Differential diagnosis initially included possible malignant or invasive pathology, which was ruled out by imaging and histopathological examination.
